I will be spoiling major twists from the series, so if you want to be completely left about the show and watch it for yourself (which I don't recommend anyways). I won't recommend you to watch this show anyways, but if you are currently watching this show or plan to watch it, it is probably best if you do not read this review. You have been warned.
Expectations are a big part of whether one enjoys a show or not, especially when talking about upcoming anime. When you see big names like Gen Urobuchi, Hiroyuki Sawano, and Ei Aoki, you can't help but get excited forwhat you assume is going to be something with quality, in both a storytelling and production aspect. That said, when the credits for episode 1 of Aldnoah.Zero rolled down my computer monitor, my expectations grew more and more. Little did I know, however, that the roller coaster that is Aldnoah.Zero is one that goes down and down until it reaches the pit of hell.


The thing that I normally like with Urobuchi's works is how he sets up the world the characters reside in. With both Psycho-Pass and Fate/Zero, everything felt so grandiose in scale, with so much detail going into the general setting of the story. And this is how Aldnoah.Zero sets itself up in the first couple episodes. We see Martians blowing up international cities all across the globe, everybody evacuating the city with terror and panic in their eyes. But then everything shrinks to the size of an earthworm. For the next number of episodes, all we really see is our main Terran characters on a ship to Russia for a long time. Other than some shots of Mars that we see occasionally, we get no info on how the war is going, almost like the ship is the world itself. 


Now, the abysmal setting of the show also provides pacing issues. Apart from a couple of fights here and there, nothing really happens during the majority of the series, even though there is a fucking war happening. It lacks any semblance of tension because of this, and the viewer is just left setting here waiting for someone to attack. This problem, however, would be more or less out the window if we had interesting, fleshed out characters with emotion and growing development as the series progressed. And for the most part, it doesn't, or it at least doesn't feel important in the slightest. But before we talk about the characters, I still have a couple more things to say about the story.


The asspulls are strong with this one. This is the problem that really gets to me when thinking about this series. This is another contributing factor to why there is a lack of tension in this series. A lot of these "big twists" are mainly shoehorned in by the writers to get a fake shock out of the viewers. Here is the big spoiler I was talking about. In the first episode, Seylum gets "assassinated" by "Terrans". Initially, I was really shocked and saddened, because I quite liked Asseylum in the beginning, and her plea to have Humans and Martians live in harmony.  But then, all that emotion I put into that shocking death scene was all gone by episode three (or four, can't really remember) when she is revealed to actually be alive, and the person who died was actually a stunt double. Shit like this just pisses me off. You can't just randomly bring back people with little to no explanation and pretend like it never happened. The cast of characters is so large, yet almost no-one who has any significance to the plot actually dies. Instead, the only people that actually die are either the enemies, or people who we really could not care less about because we haven't spent any time with them. 


This could be confusing to some people though, because in the grand scheme of things, I didn't give a damn about ANY of the characters. Because of the aforementioned ridiculously large cast, character development is very hard to come by here. Hell, most characters don't get anything other than one specific character trope that we have seen a million times over. The monotone killing machine, a princess with a heart of gold, someone with PTSD as their only defining characteristic, and even a one-dimensional loli to please those who are into that sort of thing. 


Lets get onto talking about our main protagonist, Inaho. There really isn't much to this guy. Just because he has basic military training doesn't mean he should be instantly ten times better at fighting than people in the military (which, by the way, the military is so useless in this anime, which can be considered a flaw in and of itself). He actually has no personality, no relatability, nothing. He doesn't even change his facial expression once during the entire series. And yes, you could make the argument that seeing someone who can actually get shit done rather than whining all the time is great, and for the most part, I would agree with you, but we are given no backstory to Inaho as to why he would be so cold and calculating in the first place, no fleshing out of his character. He is the way he is because it's important to the progression of the plot, and nothing more. 


We also have Slaine, the son of a Terran who did research on the power the martians have known as Aldnoah. At first, I sympathized with Slaine and his plight. He was constantly abused by Martians because of his race, and watched the only one who actually gave a damn about him die in brutal fashion, OR SO HE THOUGHT! And when he sees that the Princess is actually alive, he wants nothing but to see her again and keep her safe like she did a number of years ago. The thing is, by the end of the series he pulls an entire 180 degree switch in character for no apparent reason at all. He actually ends up siding with the guy who is trying to kill the princess, which MAKES ABSOLUTELY NO GODAMN SENSE. I don't even think he realizes that that's what the actual goal of the main villian of the series was, even though he stated it on mutiple occasions. Slaine is the biggest reason why the ending of the show is so dreadfully bad in my opinion.


And finally, we have Euphemia vi Britannia... oh wait...


Seriously though, Seylum feels like a failed clone of Euphemia from Code Geass. The princess who wants peace between two opposing sides. Like I said before, I initially liked Seylum in the first episode. From her dialogue, you could feel her desire to see the world that she has not yet witnessed, what with it's bright blue skies and flying birds, etc. The reason I could not care about her at all is that after her "dying" and coming back to life, she really loses her impact. She is still the best out of the three main characters, mainly from her pleasant demeanor, but is still wasted potential, much like the rest of this show is. 


When initially gearing myself up to watching the show, there was one thing that I was skeptical about. The animation. I, as with quite a few people, are not a big fan of CGI in anime. It just looks jarring and out of place, especially when the rest of the show is in traditional hand-drawn animation. And although the CGI mechs looked worse than they would if they were hand-drawn, it doesn't look as bad as it could've been. That being said, the mechs did not flow well, and the fights were lacking in the choreography department. I will applaud the people who actually did the designs of the mech as they were pretty unique (in a good way). As for the hand-drawn animation, it's as to be expected, nothing too spectacular but nice to look at. 


Composed by the masterful Hiroyuki Sawano, the soundtrack was something that did bring the viewing experience up slightly. However, even though I haven't any anime composed by Sawano other than Titan, I can say that, compared to that, the soundtrack had nowhere near as much impact as it did with Titan (for me at least). This might be due to the fact that the anime as a whole didn't leave an impact for me, but I don't think that if I listened to the soundtrack by itself that I would be thumping my foot to the beat as I find my self doing regularly with great soundtracks. 


I didn't really like the opening theme too much. It seemed to me like the tone and beat of the song kept switching randomly, and it felt kind of awkward. I like the chorus of the song though. The ending left a bit more of a positive impression on me because it has a little bit of 8-bit put in there. I am a big fan of 8-bit, and even though there isn't much in that song, it does warm my heart to a degree to hear it, so major props in that respect.


Aldnoah. Zero, to me, served as the perfect way to show that attaching big names who have been a part of very good anime in the past does not necessarily mean that the anime in question will be any good. This is because, to put it lightly, Aldnoah.Zero is the epitome of wasted potential. There isn't much I can think of to really give anyone a recommendation to watch this. But, many people in the community have watched it and have found something to like about it, and that is fine, but I personally cannot in good conscience recommend something that does not live up to my standards. There are much better shows with the same basic premise as this to watch, trust me.


Thanks to you all who listened to my ramblings on this show. If think my points are interesting enough to warrant a discussion, I would be happy to discuss the anime with you. My reviews tend to be way too long, so I'm glad people actually take the time to read the whole thing. I guess I have a lot of ideas to talk about, not to toot my own horn or anything. Thank you all for reading this wall of text, it truly means a lot.

(This has been adapted from my reddit thread)
Mecha-anime, a staple of the medium. No other form of media does it quite like anime when it comes to giant robots squaring off against one another for the sake of justice and survival. Aldnoah.Zero may seem like another typical robot show, but with its interesting characters, nice visuals, and killer soundtrack, it is a cut above the rest.
STORY
Our story begins with two conflicting sides, the Terrans (those of Earth) and the Vers (those of Mars). 15 years after Heaven's Fall, and after a particularly catastrophic event, these two sides begin to war with one another once again.
Aldnoah.Zeroprides itself on mech-battles. There is no shortage of fight scenes that occur throughout the show. It becomes apparent early on that this is its main focus. Usually, the show consists of our team fighting one Martian Kataphrakt (the term used for the enemy robots) for a few episodes, moving to a new location, fighting another robot, and so on and so forth. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, since many of the battles are interesting to watch. Part of the fun is seeing how Inaho, Yuki, and the rest go about taking down these leviathans of destruction using only their wimpy little machines (comparatively).


The show also takes its time building its world. We learn who he Martians are, what they fight for, and how they are able to use the mysterious power known as "Aldnoah." They create an interesting dynamic between the Terrans and the Vers that doesn't seem too far-fetched. I always enjoy societal conflicts, and I felt that AZ did this nicely enough.


One of the main problems with AZ is its lack of focus, or rather too much focus in one particular area, namely the battles. While the battles are great fun to watch, there is really no goal to be had for the show. As I said previously, much of what goes on is circumstantial. Everything is taken care of at the moment, with only the general locations of the squad changing per episode (as well as the new robot to fight). Perhaps I am expecting too much from the show, but I would have liked to have seen a grander narrative than what was presented.


As a final note, the ending is very good even if it ends on a big cliffhanger. Season two should hopefully pick up nicely where they have been supposedly left off.


ANIMATION


Aldnoah.Zero is definitely a good looking show. In terms of the art style, much of the coloring presents us with a somber attitude. A lot of the colors are dull or lackluster but serve the purpose of making us feel that the characters predicament is real and foreboding. Furthermore, because the battles are so prevalent, the backdrops and general scenery for the battles varies quite well and is always pretty to look at. From inner-city buildings to a sunset-overlooked island, the locales that are visited were always beautiful.


The actual animation for the show was good. Personally speaking, I am not a big fan of CG within anime. However, I felt that the animation during the fights was nicely choreographed, easy to follow, and overall pleasing to the eye. Many of the Martian Kataphrakts were imposing and intimidating, and gave off a nice feel of "Oh yeah, you are the bad guy for sure."


As for the character designs, I found them to be fine. I especially loved Princess Asseylum's look in her princess outfit and found Slaine's design to be both good and mysterious (given context clues throughout the show).


CHARACTERS


Whereas AZ focuses a lot on the battles, the downtime between them is mainly spent on character and character growth for the most part.


I found some of the characters within AZ to be quite good. The best among them is Slaine. Slaine experiences many tumultuous emotions throughout the series. Beginning as a Terran working with the Princess, he is a foreigner in a place where he is not wanted. What he goes through can be described as no less than suffering and it becomes wholly apparent by the end that he has fully changed as a person after the events he witnesses.


Saazbaum is also a well written character. While insane, he has clear goals and purpose for doing the things he does. It isn't just because he is evil; he has a sense of honor and pride that allows him to make such heinous acts. While what he does is fundamentally insane/evil, it is hard to argue that is character's background was flat.


Finally, Asseylum and Rayet get a nod, simply because they start off on opposite sides. The former wants peace and harmony but learns that war is not such a simple thing. The latter wants nothing but agony for the Terrans but comes to understand that there is a time and a place for compassion.


All this being said, the rest of the characters are either under-developed or severely lacking development. While Inaho is a bad-ass, his emotionless persona and general neutral demeanor does not make him a standout character. Furthermore, his sister and friends are all there to pretty much provide minimal assistance in order to let Inaho do most of the work.


The biggest letdown this season was Marito. He has an interesting background that his somewhat explored but not utilized fully, at least this season. I expect great things from him, but as it stands, his character was not given the justice it deserves.


SOUND


The OP and the ED for AZ are very good. The OP instills this sense of hope, but the female's singing gives us this aura of mysteriousness that permeates much of the show. The ED is one of the better ones I have heard in a long time. It's powerful, uplifting, and strong.


The rest of the soundtrack, simply put, is amazing. Hiroyuki Sawano of Attack on Titan and Kill la Kill fame does it once again, giving us amazing orchestral pieces that are incredibly pleasing to listen to and expertly crafted. I cannot give higher praises to this man's work.


The voice acting is also well done by each cast member. There were no absolute stand-out performances, but each VA did a nice job in their respective departments.


ENJOYMENT


In a show about giant robots, AZ does a nice job of presenting us with likable (and hate-able) characters mixed with good battle scenes that fixate your attention to what is happening on the screen. Even though I said that Inaho is not a good character, it is still fun to watch the OP dude do the impossible in order to protect the planet and its people.


Much of my enjoyment with the show was mainly due in part to Asseylum and Slaine, and wanting to see where they would end up next. I like romance a lot, and I want my couples to end up happily-ever-after if at all possible. And that is what kept me coming back for more. I wanted to know what was going to happen to these all of the characters, how they were going to overcome their next battle, and what new technology the enemy would throw at them next time.


There are some episodes that leave you wanting to watch the next episode; you just have to know what comes next. And the final episode is no different. While I am sad that I must wait three months or so for the continuation of AZ, if it will be as good as season one was, I don't mind the wait.


SUMMARY


Story: Fine, mech-battle heavy and interesting world but not much else


Animation: Good, beautiful scenes and fights with too much CG for my liking


Characters: Fine, a mix of strong and weak characters give us an interesting cast


Sound: Great, superb in every department


Enjoyment: Good, robots, love, and misery


Final Score: 7/10

Alright! It's time to watch some Turn A Gunda- WHAT THE FUCK?!
Yeah, the premise is about humans that colonized Mars that decide to take over Earth with Earth people not having that crap so it turns into war. So, Gen Urobuchi made the premise and had a hand in episodes 1-3 and 9-10. I can safely say that this wasn't nearly as good as his other works like Fate/Zero and Psycho Pass, and this is probably the worst show he had an active role in. Well, that aside, this was a pretty polarizing mech show back in 2014 for a few reasons.The questions at debate here are: "Was it as bad as our main lead?" and "How much worse is this compared to other shows the Urobutcher worked on?" Well, let's find out, shall we?


STORY: 3/10


Like I said, this premise isn't unique. This planet Mars is home to people called VERS, and they had a poor history with current Earth, and Princess Asseylum tried to patch that up, only for an assassination attempt to occur and cause big time war between VERS and Earth. It was first used in Turn A Gundam, but that isn't even the major issue given that it is still a bit different overall. Sure, it still sounds cool on paper, but it had some seams in the fabric, and over the course of the show, those seams ripped apart into giant holes, and for a more recent example, this goes in a similar direction to what Kabaneri would go in. Sure, Inaho figuring out mech weaknesses via science is cool the first few times, but then they get a bit more farfetched, and when Slaine (a VERS) decides to help him, he stabs him in the back (figuratively) and leaves him for dead in episode 7, which not only was the final nail in the coding for Inaho's character, but the moment the show jumped the shark. The whodunnit thing with the assassination isn't done well, and when the villain reveals himself, his motives clash heavily with his methods. There are definitely some plotholes and badly reasoned character decisions towards the latter half in particular, but easily the biggest slap in the face has to be the ending, which opts to shoot Asseylum and Inaho in the face to play the whole "protagonists are dead" card for a terrible cliffhanger when they are shoe for absolutely no reason. The second half was overall pretty terrible, but thus ending was the worst of it


CHARACTERS: 4/10


Meet Inaho, your average mostly silent protagonist with a nigh-nonexistent personality and an ability to be the only competent person here, to the point that he may have came out from an 80's or 90's video game. He is that lame and the fact that he (for no good reason) backstabs Slaine, who was helping him, ruined any chance of him being a passable character. Next up, we have Bad Luck Slain. A character who just wants to do the right thing as fish the princess, but gets screwed over by EVERYBODY! Asseylum herself survived the assassination attempt via body double and somehow disguised herself (it's never explained) and while very attractive, isn't that compelling. Most others are just meh. Nothing special. Now for the villains. Count ASSBUM (Saazbun) I already mentioned, but the other villains, are about as shallow and there to be evil as say, a Captain Planet villain. There really isn't much of anything of note here, aside from that one guy with a potentially interesting backstory and fleshing out if they gave him more time to leave much of an impact.


ART: 7/10


Considering A-1 pictures, their staff slaved over some well done character models and animation, as well as impressive artwork. Then, there's the subject of debate: the CGI mechs. They look kinda clunky and noticeable. However, the fight scenes are still pretty entertaining regardless, using the CGI to decent effect there, for how bad it looks and blends. The action scenes are pretty much what makes this show somewhat memorable, and not a total waste. Plus, some of the mech designs are pretty good.


SOUND: 8/10


The soundtrack is rather nice. The vocal tracks, while overused, are still pretty good. It's a pretty nice OST, even if it's only really memorable for how much they shove it into your head :p . The OP is pretty nice, and it was done by Kalafina, who previously did Fate/Zero OP 2, and while not as god as that, is still a rather nice OP. The normal ED is ok. For ED 2 aka Aliez, it is awesome. Especially the kickass chorus and finale, which oddly enough, has the most emotion of the series despite not being that emotional. It's a really badass track. The dub, is pretty nice. Our mains are pretty good, and the villains are done well too. There is some star power though, like Brice Papenbrook as one of Inaho's friends, or Patrick Seitz as Vlad. Like I said, the dub is pretty good.


ENJOYMENT: 5/10


I found the first half rather entertaining, despite the characters. Then the second half revealed all of the show's major flaws, and became pretty upsetting, especially that BS finale and episodes 9 and 10. The mech fights were still entertaining regardless, even if some of the outcomes weren't very good, and the music was still a treat, but man did I grow to dislike the second half, starting with the infuriating way episode 7 ended. Seriously, that marked the death of my enjoyment with this series as well as the death of whatever quality it had left.


OVERALL: 5/10    RAW SCORE: 52/100


This could've been rather good, but is squandered its chances to deliver us something flawed and a bit generic. It was entertaining in the first half, though not  necessarily great, by the second half really dropped the ball, especially the finale. It's not great or even that good, which is a shame given the kickass premise. If you have some time to kill, and wanna watch a mech show with that time, then maybe consider this if you REALLY have nothing else, but eh, Maybe look somewhere else first. With all that said, I bid you adieu.

Note: this review may be subjected to revision.
Ah Aldnoah Zero where do I even begin with you. 
A summer 2014 mecha anime directed by El Aoki (of Fate Zero and Ga Rei Zero fame) and animated by A1 Pictures and Troyca. It was one of my most anticipated series on the roster alongside Shinchiro Watanabe’s well directed thriller, Zankyou no Terror. I remember my heart pumping with excitement as I watched the trailer to this anime with Sawano Hiroyuki’s epic score booming from my laptop screen and Gen Urobuchi being himself again. There was destruction, there was fear and there was conflict. It looked tobe a cross between Gundam (the original one) and Legend of the Galactic Heroes and my inner nerd burst out of me with anticipation.


Only what I received wasn’t quite what I had expected. 


**Story**

The plot is relatively simple and straightforward to understand. The story begins with the Vers Empire, a Martian race, plotting to invade Earth. They then order for the assassination of the princess as an excuse to carry out their diabolical plans. As Landing Castles (in other words colonies) start dropping on to earth the invasion begins and mankind is soon fighting for survival. Meanwhile, a trainee known as Inaho discovers a sickly girl who apprehends him beneath an underpass. That girl turns out to be the real princess and she tags along with the humans to ensure that her demands for peace and the survival of the human race are to be met. 


I have no qualms about the story of Aldnoah Zero. It has a ton of potential also, depicting a War of the Worlds type invasion where Earth is being driven to the brink of extinction by alien forces. The first half is set up as a monster of the week style scenario where human forces try to hold their ground and defeat a Martian and his/her overpowered mecha.  Conflict plays a major role here and the anime shows that gleefully.


However it falls short soon enough. The human characters don’t seem to have any complaints about being in war and none of them experience any sort of trauma apart from a few. Martians seem to attack humans just for the sake of it and when their motivations for invading the planet have been revealed it just becomes laughably stupid. The biggest problem with this kind of anime is that it is meant to also be character driven. But apart from Slaine and Marito, none of the characters seem to compliment the narrative; instead they hold it back due to their overall poor characterization. Being set during an invasion the anime also seems to shy away from showing the consequences of it, instead deciding to focus on anime antics during some of the breather scenes. 


Exposition was handled terribly. Characters sometimes just stand there talking, sometimes describing things that were just not important to the overall plot. In fact in the very first episode, the anime begins with the princess talking to us about the earth’s oceans and lands and how essential they are to the overall race all while just standing there speaking to Slaine. It was a clear example of a failed attempt at the device known as “show don’t tell.” 

My biggest gripe however is with the ending. Wow what a way to end your first season Aldnoah. Basically to put it short they’ve prevented any chance of a second season occurring without an asspull happening. And indeed a second season is coming out. Prepare yourselves for an asspull guys, its coming. 


On the surface the story isn’t that bad but as it continues the flaws become apparent. The plot an pacing are okay but the execution is lousy. 


**Characters**

First off you’ll notice the show has some very bland characters that are mainly stereotypes of other archetypes. You have the generic overprotective sister, a typical high school girl who wouldn’t look out of place in taking over Shirley from Code Geass or Hare from Guilty Crown’s spot (she’s also a generic tsundere) and your everyday dumb best friend who just serves as comic relief and to only enter the action when the plot demands for him to do so. And alongside that you have some 1-dimensional villains that, if you’re a fan of mecha anime, you would have witnessed multiple times now in other shows of the same genre. 

Also the princess’s assistant is a bloody loli. A LOLI!!! This isn’t Sunrise for crying out loud. Having that character sprout “Hime-sama” just ruins the overall mood of the narrative. War isn’t meant to be funny and why is her assistant a little girl? Shouldn’t it be an older representative of the Vers royalty?


The biggest problem though is the characterization of the main character Inaho. Usually main leads in mecha anime can be characterized along the lines of being determined and somewhat naïve at the start. Inaho is skilled in mecha combat but instead of being desperate to save his world from a Martian invasion, he doesn’t give two shits about it. In fact he doesn’t care about anything or anyone for that matter. Sure he takes action like any reasonable person would but he has the same facial expression on his face the whole time. He has no personality whatsoever and because of this it’s difficult for me to even root for him. It’s like watching a literal robot acting as the hero of a tale of betrayal, greed and death. It doesn’t fit the series and is ridiculous even by Urobuchi shows standards (who tend to have dark brooding semi-emotionless heroes).  


**Animation**

A1 Pictures is known for having good animation especially if they’re funded by Aniplex. Sure they failed hard with Fairy Tail and due to popular belief, Magi but shows such as Sword Art Online, Blue Exorcist and Shin Sekai Yori have been well handled. With Aldnoah Zero being such a big property helmed by the likes of El Aoki and Gen Urobuchi, you’d expect this to have near Fate Zero levels of astounding visuals. Plus they teamed up with Troyca too. 


But nope, they even messed up the animation.


The show itself has some great set pieces and the strongholds of the Vers Empire look gorgeous. The explosions in particular look nice and visually impressive but everything else looks rather standard for mecha fare and nothing special at all. The human animations feel clunky at times and there is even some slight off model sequences going on at certain intervals. The biggest offenders are the mechas for they are completely done using poorly rendered CGI. This leads to battles looking slightly unpleasant and sometimes very jerky with its movements, an example which can be closely analyzed easily in episode 2.  It is not well integrated with the 2D animation the series offers us making it seem jarring when the 2 are mixed together. Oh and did I mention that the CGI looks like it was pulled out of a cutscene from a Japanese PS2 game. 


**Sound**

Finally something this anime manages to get right. The sound here is exceptionally well crafted by composer Sawano Hiroyuki who was responsible for such works as Guilty Crown and Attack on Titan. The preview proves this as it is littered with not only your typical Sawano tracks that you’ve heard on multiple occasions but also some ear pleasing sounds that reflect the brutality and hopelessness of war itself. The opening by Kalafina also deserves merit for being the best Kalafina song I’ve heard since the second opening of Fate Zero. The ending by Mika Kobayashi comes in two flavors; a relaxing and almost melancholic tune that accompanies the end of all episodes with the exception of one and a remix of one of soundtracks with more lyrics added that sounds much darker and more serious in tone that is only used at the end of one episode. 

The only problem I have with the sound is that the anime reuses a majority of the tracks especially for fight scenes. Other than that the sound in this anime is well deserving of a high score. 


**Overall thoughts**

I honestly wanted to like this. I absolutely adored Urobuchi’s previous works due to their dark themes, his knack for great storytelling and the amount of effort put to the table in contrast to many other anime out there. El Aoki, the director, helmed one of my most beloved series of all time, Fate Zero and having his name plastered on the front poster should have been enough to say that quality was guaranteed. But the more episodes I watch of Aldnoah the more problems become clear to my very eyes. And some of these issues are glaringly obvious and threatening to the lifespan and credibility of the series as a whole. 


Maybe I was suffering too much from hype backlash after having my hopes ruthlessly dashed? After all being a Urobuchi series, I was expecting a ton of death, despair and his usual mannerisms. But I’m guessing his departure after its first three episodes kind of made me understand why my expectations were rarely ever met. 


Aldnoah is below average to me. There were points of elevation but most of the times I just felt bored while watching it. The characters were rarely interesting, the plot was not that well executed aside from its pacing and premise and some character decisions were questionable to say the least. I’m stuck between giving this a score of a 4 or a 5 but well I have to be honest with myself. I didn’t really enjoy this series that much anyways.  


It’s also hard to recommend as well. Other anime have done better in its respective genres. Want a good mecha anime, watch Gundam, Code Geass, Eureka 7 etc. Want a great Urobuchi series, watch Fate Zero. 


I’ll wait for the second season. After all being an anime original it always ignites some suspense into me as I await further plot lines to be concluded and revelations to be shown.

WHAT AM I WATCHINGGGGGGGGGGG

Aldnoah.Zero was a good show.
That's it though. Good.
Go on any discussion for the Summer 2014 season on the internet, and the most prominent show would be Aldnoah.Zero. I mean, I was part of that hype train too. The God himself Urobuchi and the Goddesses Kaijura/Kalafina with the directing talents of once of the most prominent faces in the modern anime world, (Aoki) and you'd have the hype train to hell that was this show.  The question is, why was A/Z not literally the greatest show of all time? 
Our setting and story is quite standard, although that is not necessarily a negative. Reading theMAL description is solid enough to cover that. It's a classic battle between the weak and the strong, the inferior, and the superior. The show plays this well during its course. You feel as if there is a real war occurring, even if it may seem a bit baseless. It really gives off a Code Geass vibe, taking influence from a show such as that is definitely a strong point for A/Z. The show attempts to combine the aspects of multiple back stories for the characters, as well as the war, into one cohesive plot. This works for the most part, as some of the back stories for the characters are quite well done. (Lt. Marito.) However, this aspect stops here, because while the story regarding the war is solid, the aspect based on the other half of the plot, is well... 


And this is where the show really fell flat in one important area for me: the characters. It is simply astounding how lacking these characters are in this show.  The show cycles through a mid-sized cast, although it mainly centers around Kaizuka Inaho, who is...I don't know, to be honest. Who is this guy? One look at his bio on MAL tells me that he is a high school student who “has a peculiar interest in eggs.” There is a problem if that was literally the most interesting aspect of him in the description. I hate to break any air of professionalism that I may have kept up so far, but this character is so damned bland. I literally wouldn't be surprised if I opened up my latest edition of Merriam-Webster to find his name under the definition of the word itself. He had little back story to speak of, and almost no development in the show whatsoever. Now, it is perfectly fine for a character to be fully developed from the get go, but they have to hint at how they developed, or be slightly interesting in the first place. Inaho fails on all levels. The main character from Rail Wars (Whatever his name is) has more depth than him.


The show attempts to have another character mirror Inaho on the opposing side, Slaine Troyard. While slightly more bearable and interesting than his male lead counterpart, he still has nothing of importance to speak over. A fighter on the superior side of Vers, he has an undying loyalty towards the Princess of Vers, Asseylum, and that is honestly his only notable point. Speaking of the princess, the show does a good job of making you care for her. Every time she finds trouble, I always sympathized. However, once again, this is all to her. Notice a trend here? All of the characters in Aldnoah.Zero are one-dimensional. In depth analysis of any actions are useless, because they simply do not exist. Each character exists for one specific role in the show, and nothing more. That is just not good writing. The characters needed to be strong for this show to be strong- the story solid, but not good enough to hold the show to a high quality, and the characters failed as a pillar.


Not all is lost, however.


What A/Z does extremely well, and I mean extremely well, is the sound and visual department. These aspects of the show do more than enhance the show, they genuinely add to the show itself. Starting from the top, the OP is phenomenal. I mean, everything is done well here, as the song provides the backdrop for each episode- it thrusts the viewer into each episode. It is very well done, as the visuals for the OP add on to the already phenomenal job done by Kaijura and Kalafina. Kaijura also works magic into the show itself. Battles feel epic and important, even if it was just the product of the lacking story. The BG adds an atmosphere, and does it damned well. Pair this up with the visuals now: while not of the highest  quality in recent years, certainly do fall under the category of high quality. Backgrounds are vibrant and well done, and still shots do well of portraying emotion. The show does suffer from wonky  faces and animation from time to time, however, which unfortunately, has become a sort of a standard. The voice talent for the show mainly consists of a mix between very modern seiyuu who will undoubtedly become popular in the next few years, and already established seiyuu. There is a lot of talent here, and while not a show-saver, the acting is clearly done well.


So in the end, A/Z rounds out to be a show with a decent story, low quality characters a strong soundtrack/visual aspect. I really did want to enjoy this show more, but I just could not. A/Z has failed on many levels, and simply does not deserve a large amount of praise. The ending was actually quite entertaining, the last episode being of high quality. Unfortunately, the show's weak points certainly marred it, and it did allude to a second season or movie heavily. (I mean it's already announced for January.) Considering all of this, is the show bad? Not at all. 7/10, according to MAL, is good.


That's it though... Good.


Have fun.

Aldnoah.Zero Review (Redo) 
	I’ve decided to re-write my review for this show, as I feel I did not effectively convey my feelings for this show, nor elaborate enough upon the characters and goings on within it. As such, I’m putting more thought into this new review. It’s quite longer and to my opinion a little disjointed, but overall I’m more or less satisfied. 
When the credits rolled on the twelfth episode of Aldnoah.Zero, quite a few thoughts went through my mind. Principle among them was why I made the decision to watch the series in one go, I felt like I had essentially wasted fourhours of my day, this is not a good show. I consider it to just be bad, plain and simple, though the finale, which I will get to later, is a standout because it outdoes itself and winds up being terrible.


The story of Aldnoah.Zero, such as it is, tells of an invasion of Earth from the Mars-based Vers Empire, a technologically superior offshoot of Humanity that stemmed from astronauts finding advanced technology on the Moon during the Apollo missions of the 1970's. The technology was left over from an advanced alien civilization that had since vanished and somehow a group of people got a hold of it, traveled to Mars, and founded the empire. The Vers Empire is a monarchy with the usual aristocratic titles, with various nobles, or knights, living away from Mars in giant orbital stations above the Earth. These Knights have been in orbit for the past fifteen years since the first Martian incursion on Earth, the oft-mentioned Heaven’s Fall, and are non-too pleased to be there. [Spoilers] Thus, a faction of these Knights hatch a scheme to assassinate  Princess Asseylum, granddaughter of the leading regent of the Vers Empire, and who is embarking on a mission of peace to Earth, using her death as an excuse to invade the Earth and take it for themselves. [End Spoilers] Humanity of course isn’t going to take this invasion laying down, the United Earth Government does its best to combat the Martian forces, but to no avail. The Knight’s Kataphracts, giant, technologically superior mech units are way beyond the capabilities of Earth’s own mechs and other military forces and lay waste to anyone in their path. Anyone, that is, who is not Inaho Kaizuka or nearly any of the named cast of characters that accompany him through the show, as things generally go in a series like this. However, it is with the character of Inaho that my criticisms of this show begin. 


There are three main characters in Aldnoah.Zero: 


-	Inaho Kaizuka, the leader of the group of high school kids that get swept up in the war and the walking stereotype of teenaged-mech pilots these days. He’s emotionless, distant and a genius on the battlefield, managing to either defeat or hold his own against the various Knights that show up over the course of the show, out-strategizing veteran military commanders and kicking ass. In a training mech, no less. Now, this is a tried and true character-type that is quite common in Anime as of late and while I’m not overly critical of that as a whole, when it comes to Inaho I’m not so forgiving. The show never explains why he’s this good or seemingly emotionally empty, he just is, despite having a loving sister and a tight circle of friends. I would that some slack, but with my overall opinions of this show being generally negative (which I’ll get to shortly), it’s just something else that piles on. 


-	Princess Asseylum, granddaughter of the current regent of the Vers Empire, who survived the assassination attempt against her by actually being there. A double was in her place, ala another certain princess in the Star Wars universe, and spends the most of the next several episodes disguised as a human along with her maid, Eddelrittuo. She is kind-hearted and surprisingly well-developed, who feels immense guilt for coming to Earth and, in her mind, causing the war in the first place. She becomes increasingly important to the surviving group later in the show, which I can’t get into as that gets too deep into spoiler territory. 


-	The third main character is Slaine Troyard, a Terran (as the inhabitants of Earth are called) who found his way on Mars several years ago and is now in some position in the Vers military (I think) under the watchful eye of a Knight named Count Cruhteo, who strikes Slaine with his cane for any infraction or break in protocol, no matter how slight. Terrans are viewed with disgust by Vers and Slaine is treated rather poorly by everyone he comes in contact with, all except the Princess Asseylum, whom it is strongly hinted he has feelings for. Slaine has proved to be a controversial character, dividing fans by his actions in the finale, which I will be sure to cover, spoilers and all at the end of this review. I for one am on the anti-Slaine side and the news that he is to be the main character of the second season starting in January is quite disappointing for me to hear. 


Now, one of my main criticisms of Aldnoah.Zero is in the Vers Empire itself, I just don’t buy the plausibility of its existence in the form it is in the show. The empire was formed in the 1970’s, as I said before, and by the time of the events in this season it has been in existence for a scant forty some-ought years, yet it is treated as if it has been around for much longer. I’m not on board with the idea that a presumably large group of human colonists travelled to Mars from 1970’s Earth and willingly subjugated themselves to an aristocratic and iron-fisted system of government, nor do I accept the deep-rooted anti-Terran prejudice that seems prevalent in the empire. The Vers see humanity as an inferior species, with many characters referring to them as mere “insects” repeatedly throughout the course of the show. Now, I know that people are capable of hating each other over stupid reasons, history is a testament to that fact, but for the citizens of Vers to view humanity with such prejudice I think requires a skip in logic. Again, the empire has only been in existence for forty years…that’s two, three generations at best. I cannot believe that all these Knights and the regular citizens of Mars hold such Nazi-like views of the inhabitants of Earth, whenever they are descendants of them and who all have grandparents and for some probably even parents that are Earth colonists. It just seems nonsensical to me.  


Another criticism I have for the show is that the human characters just aren’t all that developed, nor share that much in the way of screen time. The three exceptions to this are Inaho, his former instructor Lieutenant Koichirō Marito, a man who survived the Heaven’s Fall event fifteen years ago and is suffering from PTSD and Captain Darzana Magbaredge, commander of the assault ship that the cast of human characters spend the majority of the show within. Everyone else is just there seemingly to remind the audience that other people besides Inaho exist on the Earth and that he went to high school at some point. They are quite under-developed and quite frankly 

largely useless to the overall plot. 


My last criticism before delving into the positives for a little while is the 

main story itself, but with this I’m not especially critical. With few exceptions, I found the goings on to be rather boring, sure most of the fights were neat and machinations and reasoning behind the assassination conspiracy turned out to be interesting, but everything else was pretty boring. Inaho Kaizuka pretty much dominated the storyline and I found him so boring and unlikable that it bled out to the rest of the show and the finale was the cherry on top for my feelings of dislike. 


Now for the positives, the animation and sound. The animation of Aldnoah.Zero, while not anything outstanding, is nonetheless great. It is clean and solid, with no dips in quality throughout the entire series and with some truly stunning effects during some of the larger battle scenes. The battles are likewise greatly helped by excellent sound design, I’d say that this show has some of the better-sounding battles in recent memory. Coupled with that is an amazing musical score, definitely the highlight of the series for me, it was great and I hope the same composer is on board for season two. I don’t normally buy anime soundtracks, but I might just make an exception in this case. Last but certainly not least for sound is the voice cast, which to my ears sounded just fine, no issues with a single character. Worthy of high praise, I’d say. 


Okay, going into quasi-spoilers for the close of this review, so be warned. Of everything I disliked about Aldnoah.Zero, the finale to this season just made everything worse and made me feel that I had wasted a full four hours. At the climax of the twelfth episode, following the successful attack against a Vers orbital platform that had landed on the Earth’s surface to attack Earth HQ and with its commander, Count Saazbaum, leader of the assassination conspiracy, making an effort to finally kill the Princess, the three main characters encounter each other in the same place for the first time. Inaho was close to defeating Saazbuam before both of them being crashed into by a craft piloted by Slaine, who had spent the past few episodes trying to find the Princess and save her. The Princess ran towards Inaho in order to see if he was still alive and after finding that he is, with Slaine watching it all, she is shot twice by the Count and seemingly killed. Slaine in an emotional fury nearly empties his pistol into Saazbaum, but cannot bring himself to kill him, for whatever reason. All the while, Inaho, badly wounded, is crawling towards the Princess, with memories of their time together flashing through his head, perhaps hinting that he was finally feeling some emotion for a change. He is instructed to stop by Slaine, who has his pistol pointed at him, with Inaho responding by raising a pistol of his own which gained him a shot to the head. The ending text says that the Princess’ whereabouts are unknown. 


That’s a fairly paraphrased version of events of the finale, but for those who’ve seen the show they know the complete circumstances. My reaction to that pivotal scene was a big WTF, I was completely in the support of Slaine throughout the whole show, particularly after the brutal torture he went through, but then he went and ended the season by sparing the man who admitted to his face that he wanted to kill the Princess and would let nothing stop him and killing the one other person besides him who cared for her as much as he did. Inaho has his flaws, but he protected Asseylum with all his strength and while it is a novel idea that a main character die at the end of a series, the circumstances are something that I obviously have a problem with. The one time in the entire show that he does something eliciting interest in me and he’s repaid with a bullet, by a kid who up into that point had made some pretty brave and reasonable actions. It’s just all incredibly frustrating. Despite my dislike of this show, I will be watching the second season, if only for the hope that Slaine gets his comeuppance, preferably with the Princess rejecting him and everything he had done.

*This is a review of both Season 1 and 2.*
Did you know: the quote "Fiat justitia ruat caelum" is Latin for "Let justice be done though the heavens fall." It is most commonly used to state that justice should be achieved regardless of the cost. Quite a noble statement if I do say so myself. Surely, having an anime rally around such powerful words shouldn't be too harmful, right? Well, to summarize my feelings about Aldnoah.Zero, I would say the story fell before justice was even done.
Aldnoah.Zero places us in a world where there is one faction of humans who have left Earth to goto Mars (or a.k.a. Vers in the anime) after the discovery of a powerful technology called the Aldnoah. Just like how Forerunner technology is worshipped in the Halo franchise, the Martians establish their social hierarchy around who can activate this Aldnoah. Of course, due to the fact that Mars is, as we know it today, an inhabitable planet, the Martians decide to conquer Earth. Sounds like H.G. Wells' War of the Worlds… Anyway, enter Inaho, a poker-faced high school student who just needs a pair of shades to complete his poker-face wardrobe, is tasked, along with his friends, to face the all-mighty and clearly superior Kataphrakts (the name of the giant robots) of the Vers Empire. Will he succeed? Why of course not…right…?


This is where I believe the story begins to fall apart. While I do respect Inaho's wits, after the first few episodes, it gets repetitive. While this structure may be good if you watch each episode a week or a few days apart, marathoning Aldnoah.Zero would reveal how dry the action sequences get.  Live. Destroy. Repeat. Further, you will most likely end up thinking "Oh my, I wonder how this evil dude will get finished off" before the battle even starts.


Stepping away from all the action, the writers do attempt to incorporate some forms of drama between the characters. But much like watching a burlesque dancer reveal part of her thigh, I get seduced, however, if I make any advances, I will only get bitch slapped and rejected. In Aldnoah.Zero, I wanted to see certain characters get together and much to my pleasure, the writers were leading me on. But all I was lead to was a dead end with 1000 slaps to the face and a kick from behind as part of the completion reward. Before I passed out, all I heard from the writers was that "What were you expecting?" 


Aside from the drama, you would expect that given such an epic justice quote (remember that one?), the anime should have a good rallying theme. Nope. You don't get that with Aldnoah.Zero. The story struggled with itself in trying to incorporate that theme. At times, the story was forcibly trying to insert themes of achieving justice by any means but that was just said and done. Eventually, I think the writers saw it as a lost cause and abandoned it for some more in-depth character development. It's such a pity because it could have been so much more. Looks like the quote is used only to make the anime sound epic: "Let justice be done though heavens fall." It does have a nice ring to it.


The characters are alright at best. My favourite characters are Inko, Lt. Marito, and Rayet simply because I thought they were the more fleshed out characters. They had their desires, strengths, fears, and hate, while everyone else was just a blank slate. 

While Slaine is not one of my favourites, he gets a lot of development in the second season, which was good to see. 

Inaho was just plain cold. His personality was the main reason that I dropped the show after 4 episodes (I only picked it up again because I thought I should finish what I started). While I am certain there are people who are very calm under stress, I don't think it is impossible to feel absolutely zero emotion for your teammates or make a decision purely on logic. Inaho might as well be an android for all that matters. 

Princess Asselyum, while she has a warm heart, she does not have the necessary characteristics to lead an entire nation. She is simply too naïve to the ways of the political realm. I want to talk a little bit about her character at the end so if you haven't seen the anime yet, skip down to the END SPOILER marker.





-----SPOILER WARNING!!-----


And that ending…the writers just had her emotionlessly throw her feelings out the window and leave the story to end at that. While I can make out the political motivation for her marriage, the story offered very little guidance as to how she arrives at that decision. It was the anime's version of a bitch slap.



----END SPOILER----





On the technical aspect of the anime, the graphics were pretty stunning. I am not a huge fan of mecha anime but I don't by any means dislike it. Giant fighting robots are pretty damn cool. Coming from that perspective, I was pretty satisfied with the cool Kataphrakt designs and battle sequences. As for the character designs and colour palette, I didn't have my socks blown off but I wasn't terribly disappointed either. 


The sound is definitely a huge highlight. From the composer who brought you the epic track of Attack on Titan, Sawano Hiroyuki's score definitely impressed my ears once again. His music was basically the glue that held the entire story together. Without it…I don't even dare imagine. And as an added bonus, Kalafina (from Fate/Zero second season opening and ending of Fate/Stay Night - UBW) performs the opening to the first season. One does not simply skip a song by Kalafina.


Overall, once I got past my despair that the characters aren't going to get anywhere, Aldnoah.Zero was entertaining. It had an easy-to-follow storyline, the eye-candy, and the epic music to accompany all those explosions. Dare I say, I would recommend this anime to anyone who watches a mecha anime here and there. If you are looking for interesting characters or simply good character development, I'm afraid Aldnoah.Zero does not have those items on the menu. Please go to the store next door titled [insert a better mecha anime here].



Let me know what you liked or disliked about Aldnoah.Zero! Do we have a similar perspective on this anime or just absolutely polar opposite? Do let me know because I would love to hear from you!

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS
*ahem* 
In a nutshell, this is a fairly entertaining anime, with some exciting action sequences, good plot twists, and an awesome soundtrack. Unfortunately, it suffers from rather flat, stereotypical characters, and a run-of-the-mill storyline that you might find in any other mecha anime.
Story: 6/10
The plot revolves around the interplanetary conflict between the forces of United Earth and Vers Empire (Mars).  War breaks out, and a few highschool kids with military training in using Katephrakts (giant robots - I know, right?) get caught up in the mix and must fight to protect Earth against the invading Martians. Does that sound familiar? Needlessto say, the main plotline is rather weak,  but fortunately has some darn good plot twists which keep it from getting a lower rating.


Art: 6/10


The character art is drawn in a simplistic style, and brings across emotion well, though is not overly dramatic. As for the environmental art, it is well-varied and provides good backdrops for anime's scenes. The main complaint that I have is with the CGI for the Katephrakts, which is pretty clunky looking, and is sometimes painfully noticeable. However, this is only occasional, and is compensated with fast-moving camera angles, so it doesn't drag down the rating too much. Overall, the art doesn't break any beauty records for me, but it does the job.


Sound: 8/10


The soundtrack for this anime is pretty awesome, incorporating some rather epic choir/rock mixes for the action scenes and poignant piano pieces for the more emotional scenes. I seriously have to look up some of this music on Youtube and add it to my epic study playlist later.



Character: 5/10


I generally place anime characters into 3 categories: 

- Good, with lots of interesting character development, mixed in with deep, fleshed out personalities. 

- Bad, with the main characters either having no character development at all or are just downright annoying and serve no purpose to the plot. 

- Mediocre, where the main characters are interesting enough, but are just too stereotypical/unrelateable and weren't given enough time to be fleshed out. 

Aldnoah Zero I am placing in the last category, as mediocre. The characters aren't completely unlikeable, and have some darn good voice acting which helps with this. Unfortunately, the personalities that the three main characters were given all fall into the common anime tropes - we have Asseylum playing the innocent, pure-as-snow, kawaii princess who wouldn't hurt a fly; Slaine acting as the "wounded puppy" , who is a good guy but gets beaten up on by everyone, for seemingly no good reason other than to make the audience get the feels; and then Inaho, who has absolutely no character at all and comes across as completely unrelateable. Seriously, he could be a robot for all the emotion he shows, because I think I've only seen him smile once, maybe twice in the entire first season, and JUST BARELY at that (like seriously, you would have missed it if you weren't paying attention). The secondary characters don't really do the rating any favours, especially with practically all of the antagonists falling under the "arrogant rich kid" role. I wish I could give this a higher rating, because some of the characters in this anime had such potential, but ended up falling flat as none of them were given time to develop their characters and so fell into common anime stereotypes.


Enjoyment: 7/10


Despite this anime's failings, I still enjoyed watching it, due to the entertaining plot twists and action sequences, which kept me interested. The only thing in this section I feel I need to complain about is that after a while the pacing of the battles starts to feel quite similar:


*Villain shows up*

Villain: "Nya-ha-ha I am rich and powerful and I have a bigger gun than you so KNEEL BEFORE ME etc. etc."

Good guys: "Oh no, whatever shall we do? He's too strong!"

Inaho: "I'm here to save the day!"

Good guys: "Yay!"

*Inaho thinks up some brilliant plan and destroys Villain*

Villain: "NOOOO, HOW COULD THIS HAPPEN TO MEEE blah blah blah"


Still, the action sequences were varied enough so as to keep the rather repetitive pacing hidden for a while, thus keeping the rating at a solid 7. However, I reeeeeally wish the villains were more interesting because the whole rich-and-arrogant routine gets old pretty fast.


Overall: 7/10


Yes, Aldnoah Zero suffers from mediocre characters, a sub-par plot, and lame CGI, but for some reason I still enjoyed watching it despite these rather debilitating flaws. I suppose the great plot twists, the cool action sequences and the beautiful soundtrack coupled with the nice voice acting was enough to satisfy my anime-itch. Will I rewatch? Probably not, but I definitely don't regret watching it in the first place.

TL;DR - Like clay, so much potential in the right hands, but it's a mess in the end.
Watching Aldnoah.Zero is like watching a Jackie Chan movie.  You would be amused by the crazy stunts and the perfectly choreographed fight scenes.  But if you watch it for the plot, you would be disappointed.  Aldnoah.Zero is visually and aurally brilliant (much like Jackie's stunts and fights), but in the overall scheme of things, it does not live up to the sum of its parts.
GOOD - Animation
Very few anime could boost stunning animation.  Aldnoah.Zero is one of the few.  Everything from the backgroundto the mecha decor, from the explosion to the energy beam, the attention to details is nothing short of exquisite.  Some people might complain about the use of CGI, but personally I find it enhances the show greatly.  It is still not as fluid as it should, but for what it's worth, it makes the scene livelier.


Mecha design is meticulously done.  Each Martian Kataphrakt have its unique style.  It is good to see that they are not your typical humanoid design.  The designers must be commended for creating something different.  Even though all Kataphrakts on Earth is the standard issue (i.e. they all look the same), Inaho's Kataphrakt managed to have accessories which make it unique in its own right.


GOOD - Mecha Fighting Scenes


Fighting scenes are great insofar as the duel between Inaho and the "Martian Kataphrakt of the Week (TM)" is concerned.  Inaho's calm nature and ability to collect, analyse and take the most logical option is like watching a super computer in action.  He is emotionless and will only take what he thinks is the best possible path to complete the mission at hand, disregarding normal things like orders.  There is nothing more satisfying than to see the underdog wins against all odds.


GOOD - Music To The Ears


The soundtrack of Aldnoah.Zero is superbly done.  The background music is upbeat and fits the situation like a glove.  Tension in the battle scenes, tender in the mellow scenes.  There is not one beat out of place.


The OP and ED are great.  Usually I would skip the OP and ED, but the songs made me stay every episode.  The ED song aLIEz is especially well done.  The upbeat tempo and the tension in the music is perfect for a morale boosting song.  If only the Kataphrakts has an iPod connection or bluetooth.  I can imagine the pilots listening to the song every time they go out to battle.


BAD - The Epic Battle Everyone is Waiting For (or Lack Thereof)


If you like watching epic battles between troops, then you will be sorely disappointed with Aldnoah.Zero.  Yes, I know I said before that I like the fight scenes, but it is only insofar as a duel between the two people concerned.  The entire Martian invasion strategy involves the Count landing his/her castle somewhere on Earth and dispatch that one Kataphrakt (that only the Count can control) to wreak havoc on Earth, while the rest of the Martians sit inside the landing castle having a tea party, presumably.  That's like the General does all the fighting while the rest his army sits idle inside the barrack.  And guess what, the General who is supposedly well trained in using his super weapon to his absolute advantage is actually pretty crap against a high school kid who uses a training mecha and much inferior weaponry.  All you need is knowing how physics works.  So don't skip your physics class, boys and girls.


BAD - The Usefulness Of The Earth Military (or Lack Thereof)


While it is natural to see Inaho and his peers dodging, sidestepping and generally avoid things that could end their lives, the rest of the military forgets what "avoiding being killed" means.  Characters who are required for the plot conveniently survive every attack ranging from the mecha losing an arm to losing a head.  For all the other pilots who never spoken to Inaho (i.e. not important), they are just some useless pink garden flamingos begging to be vandalised.  They serve only two functions: a) to make the main characters look good and b) scream like a little girl who had her Barbie ran over by a tank.


BAD - Backstory (or Lack Thereof)


There is not much story to speak of generally, but the backstory is almost non-existent.  We are given a 5 minute lecture on the Vers Empire and another 5 minutes lecture on the reason for the First Vers-Earth War.  But there are so many back stories that would provide a much richer understanding of the world that Aldnoah.Zero is set in.  But then again, the Vers Empire has only been in existence since 1972 (the anime is set in 2014), so there is hardly any history to be had.


Slaine is an interesting character in his own right, but we have no idea of his origin other than that he and his father crash landed on Mars years ago.  Why the hell did they come to Mars in the first place?  Were they being chased by space pirates?  Was Slaine tricked by his dad with a promise of limitless candy?  Were they prosecuted for being devil worshipers on Earth?  How did they even evade the Mars defence when they come crashing in?  These are the sort of questions that were never answered in the series, and likely never will (great potential for some creative fanfics, though).


UGLY - (Virtually No) Character Development


There is virtually zero character development in the series.  Inaho is super smart but has the personality of a garden gnome.  While he is not the first anime character to exhibit these traits (and certainly won't be the last), he is just so cold and is more like a computer than human.  His care factor is absolute zero.  Watching his friend died in front of his eyes and winning against a death machine has the same effect on him.


Princess Asseylum fills in the shoes of someone who is an idealist who thinks that she can "save the world" without resorting to violence.  Unfortunately there are already plenty of hers around in every anime that involve epic wars between two sides.  Her function as a character lacks conviction.  Sure, she serves more function than just some 1960's hippies, but Asseylum seems to be the only person at that anti-war rally as everyone else is eager to go to war.


Slaine is possibly the most interesting character out of the three main cast.  He represents the pinnacle of pain and suffering, but his role is confusing, we don't know where he stands in the Martian society.  He is despised by every Count who knows of him, yet he seems to hold substantial status over ordinary Martians, so which is which?  He is deeply loyal to Princess Asseylum, probably because she is his only friend.  But his action says otherwise.


The rest of the supporting cast is unfortunately just as shallow.  They show more emotion than Inaho, but their care factor is just as low.  People are dying left, right and centre and all they care about is "the military uniform doesn't look good on me".


The Martian Orbital Knights, saved for a few main Counts who are required for the plot, are meant to be all powerful with their death machines decimating the populace on Earth.  But the only thing they managed to decimate is the writer's credibility as they turn from their God-like status to utterly useless and became nothing more than the "Martian Kataphrakt of the Week (TM)".  One minute, they were sweeping the floor with a decapitated Earth Kataphrakt.  The next minute, they were the one that got swept into the dumpster.


There is no chemistry between the characters.  Friendship between Inaho and Princess Asseylum stayed the same way throughout the series.  Relationship between Inaho and Slaine is fuelled by the misunderstanding of each other just because they wear a different uniform.  The show would have ended peacefully many moons ago if only the three of them would sit down and talk to each other over dinner.


There is no team work to speak of between Inaho and the rest of his platoon.  The writer made him so overpowering that makes everyone else looks insignificant.  They might as well sit with the audience and watch the Inaho one man show instead.


Aldnoah.Zero makes it very hard for the audience to like, let alone relate, to the characters.


CONCLUSION


Despite all its shortcomings, Aldnoah.Zero is enjoyable to watch if you can ignore its fault.  But saying that is like saying you are a good person if only you didn't murder your mother.  Aldnoah.Zero has great potential.  In fact, I actually enjoyed watching it the first time round.  It is only when I started thinking about it deeper that I realised how flawed it is.  If you do end up watching the first season, I strongly urge you to commit to the second cours as well.  The ending is just too much to bear.

5/10 Story

Lots of plot holes, not very well done/thought out, could use work. There wasn't much of a story line present, in my opinion. Sure, the anime flowed nicely, but there wasn't much of an actual story. The basis is that there is an antagonist who has a grudge against a whole being and wants to destroy it and the protagonists were pulled into that plot. Background info wasn't discussed very much and neither was the plot of the villain. We just got the basic gist of things. It was way more action oriented. Some plot twists were thrown in and a portion were good and the other seemed to be thrown in just for the twist. Somewhat predictable. Subjectively, the ending sucked. Objectively, the ending didn't make much sense to the story flow. It was abrupt and needs explanation, however the anime says that it will be explained in January 2015, so we must wait a while if it does come out. It was just nonsense.

3/10 Characters/Character Development

This will be divided into three categories/subjects: Development, Villains, General Characters.

Development- not much back story or development present. A lot of unanswered questions about characters and relationships. Characters were pretty unmemorable since you couldn't really build a connection with them or follow them very closely throughout the anime. Most of the focus was on fight scenes or the like. You do grasp the outline of the main characters, but the secondary characters are lost in the story. Who are they? Why are they there? Do they even matter? They do not get much screen time, if any. 


General Characters- Empty profiles, as touched upon in the section above. You either know very little or nothing at all for each character. There isn't much depth, although there is a personality for many of the characters. About 3 of them have an actual back story: Slaine, Count Saazbaum, and Lt. Marito. I guess you can say the captain has half a back story, but it doesn't get elaborated upon at all. Disappointing, really. Could use a lot of work.


Villains- Horrible motives, poor evil plot. At best, I can describe them as petty. There is only one person who really has a reason for any of the violence, and that is Count Saazbaum. However, his justification isn't enough for the all-out apocalyptic war he initiates, and he doesn't even explain part of his plot, which is to kill a certain someone, that, for the sake of spoiling, I will not reveal. Everyone else involved doesn't seem to have a legitimate reasoning. They've all been ingrained with a degree of hatred for the terrans, but what kind of justification does that give to try and destroy Earth? Resentment that would have otherwise been kept in was just catalyzed by Saazbaum's personal revenge-seeking. All of this could have been avoided, or done differently. Saazbaum surely had numerous ways to avenge whatever it was, right? But no one questions him. Huh.

As a fan of Ei Aoki's work, and after Re:Creators cemented his directing style as one of my favorites, I felt a slight obligation to check out Aldnoah Zero, a series reputable for how dogshit it is (at least amongst the anime fans i associate with)
Needless to say, that popular opinion is on point... mostly.
iI would be prudent for me to say that while this series is bad, and I mean REALLY BAD, I still want to point out that there are a small number of things about this series that were actually decent, if not good. 
First of all, the score by Hiroyuki Sawanois expectedly quite good, and often helps to make the endless horribly written action scenes be a bit exciting. And the directing does a bit more to compensate for shit writing and dully written scenes as well.


There were MANY action scenes that, from a writing standpoint, had really lame scenarios, and characters enacting contrived tactics. But the way the scenes are shot, and the competent use of music made them enjoyable enough. However, that doesn't make the action scenes good per se. Like I said, they are still ultimately bogged down in shit writing. But at least on a base level, these scenes managed to be like a 6/10 at best.


One other thing positive worth pointing out are the CG Mechs, and a couple of their designs. A common thing I hear from people are that the CG mechs suck and appear really jarring and out of place. Personally, I think this point comes from people just having a general stigma against CG, and lets that bias inform how the percieve the mechs in this show. I thought the CG was quite well done, and had genuine quality to them. They felt like a part of the world, and often where shown from angles, or shots that obscured any imperfections you'd expect to be there.


Unfortunately, while I do think the CG is well done, it's not exactly ALWAYS like that. Some of the designs lend themselves better to being rendered in CG, and some, namely the martian Mechs, don't. Their sleeker, clean designs make their CG nature feel more obvious. Whereas the bulkier, more gritty Terran mechs look pretty good bydirect comparison.


That, however, is the last of any praise I can give this series, because EVERYTHING ELSE IS COMPLETE CRAP; and by "everything" I mean the story and characters.



Right out the gate, things aren't looking up; because the premise was instantly boring to me. The story is about two factions of humans, one hailing from Mars, with superior technology, and the other being the unremarkable Earthling type. They have some lore explaining this; but it's presented in a really dry way (as is almost all of the expository dialogue). I don't quite know how to explain what is so boring about the story itself. It's just so... unremarkable, I guess? It's just some lame-ass war with mechs in it. There's just nothing special about it. Read the synopsis for yourself if you don't believe me. It just some basic conflict between two factions.


The two factions aren't interesting in any way. The folks on Earth are just bland. We know a few things about their culture, like how they give military training to teenagers because they are paranoid about another war starting with the Martians, but that's reall all there is to them. The Martians more or less get a similar treatment, albeit with a bit more fleshing out as the series went on. Basically, they are racist against Terrans and want to take over Earth because they were too stupid to terraform Mars before colonizing it. That may sound interesting, but any chance of it being so is crushed by the overwhelmingly dull and flat way we learn that information (tactless expository dialogue).


The cast pretty much has the same problem. With the added bonus of being mostly forgettable. The main three character I can at least remember the names and faces of, but the entire supporting cast are about as memorable as what I ate for breakfast on this exact date, 5 years ago. Not that there is much to remember though, as almost all of them get very little, if any, genuine characterization. Any characterization they do get hardly felt like it mattered or added anything worthwhile to the narrative. Such as that one guy's whole PTSD issue that didn't matter or go anywhere.


The main characters don't even have character arcs (Well, i guess Slaine was supposed to, but I can't tell if it is or not, because he seems to just act without thinking).


Inaho, the supposed protagonist is about as boring and monotone as the performance given by whoever played him. his one defining character dynamic is that he is smart. And the series shows us this by having him pull mastermind battle strategies out of his ass. 


Oh, and the Princess is just kinda there, and nice, and pretty. And that's about it...

This all may seems reductive, but the really is just so little to actually say about any of these characters. They didn't even leave a strong enough impression for me to care about properly describing them anyway (not that I didn't)


One last thing that must be said, that I haven't seen being discussed, is how unappealing the aesthetic of the show is. For all the decent directing, and the cool shots, The color pallette of this show is just constant, perpetual GREY. There were times where I felt completely inundated in nothing but neutral tones. So many of the baclgrounds are dominated by GREY steel/metal, or GREY rubble, or GREY concrete structures. CONSTANT GREY, GREY, GREY EVERYWHERE. Shots might be well framed, but characters are drowning in GREY. I AM DROWNING IN GREY. WE ARE ALL DROWNING IN GREY.


Seriously, this show is dominated by that one, really drab color. It's not like you can't do anything good with grey tones. But Aldnoah Zero goes overboard with how lacking in variety the colors are. And the characters are often pretty lame too.



So in conclusion, this series is a drab mess of bad writing, a boring story, dull and forgettable characters, an all too G R E Y  A E S T H E T I C, and some pretty decent directing and music to make the overall package at least bearable enough to watch completion.


Would not recommend. Don't touch this series with a ten foot pole unless treating it as some weird case study.
