Aldnoah Zero's characters are obviously the biggest problem with the show as a whole, poorly created characters accompanied by a mediocre script at best, not a very good foundation for a show that was advertised as the next big Gen Urobuchi show. However even with his aid it still fell short. Being the man behind the story of Aldnoah Zero he laid the base for its creation, however after that point it was up to the rest of the crew to pull their weight and put forward as much if not more creativity. Unfortunately it is pretty obvious that most of the problems come up in the finer details rather than the show as a whole. Returning to my main point regarding the flawed and uninteresting characters, we have our main protagonist Kaizuka Inaho who is characterized by almost no traits at all. Throughout the show we are lead to believe that he is supposed to embody the strong silent archetype, however we are never really given any explanation as to why he is that way as a character. He constantly goes about making decisions that have serious weight in his world, however we are never introduced to his motivations, or any explanation as to why he takes such actions. The only time where we are even given a slight justification behind his character is in the ninth episode during some casual chatter between his sister Yuki and his friend Calm; wherein his sister describes him as not being as expressionless and cold as we are lead to believe, and that in fact there are very minute changes in his personality that are noticeable in certain situations, and that it is most noticeable around the Vers princess. This would make for an interesting point if it were truly the case. In reality he isn't truly a deep character who is characterized by his ability to analyze battle situations. While that may have been the case in the first battle with a martian kataphrakt (the robots), in which we are shown a fleshed out analysis of the situation, which leads to its eventual destruction through much effort and tribulation (note how this all happens in the episodes written by Gen Urobuchi), however in the following fights it seems as if instead of solving a puzzle the main character just pulls a bunch of convenient situations out of his ass. To top it off, while sure he might be able to figure out how to defeat the enemies at times, why is it always him who figures it out. Is the show implying that some random boy is more capable than the entirety of earth's military?\n
A lot of people have qualms with the story saying: “it is ridden with plot holes, none of which do the show any justice”, I however must disagree. I found that the premise was a refreshing take on a sci-fi space drama. Instead of it being aliens that are directly taking over the whole of the human race, it instead the humans corrupted by greed and power thanks to alien technology. It was a new and interesting premise that had me on the edge of my seat a lot of the time. These supposed plot holes that so many people complain about are often the result of the sci-fi genre. When you tell a story supposedly taking place in the future with advanced technologies that we have no understandings of, we cannot call such things plot holes. While the characters may have enough smudges in explanation and characterization to cover the entire planet, the plot is facing no such problems; not yet at least (good job season 2 for breaking the mold). Unexpected plot twist that don’t go over the top of your head (except for that one scene in the end) accompanied by good pacing that doesn’t leave you questioning what happened Serves up a very interesting premise that will enthrall most if not all of its viewers.\n
If I had to pin down a few points in which I felt that Aldnoah Zero did well, one of those would be the animation, however like many aspects of the show, when you look past its front you notice several flaws with its execution. Mech shows tend to be the prime offenders when it comes to over use of CG in order to cut down on the budget. Aldnoah Zero is no exception to this principle, unfortunately the kataphrakts are done with CG, and while they are not jarring like how most computer generated objects are (in fact they blend in quite well with the rest of the show), it is still annoying how often they throw in a three dimensional object into a two dimensional scene. It shows several things, but the main point that it shows is a lack of desire to give life to the show; simply put it is lazy and it pisses me off. I personally don’t tend to enjoy shows centered entirely on the fact that there are mechs, instead shows such as this, Code Geass, and Neon Genesis where the mechs are just used as part of the narrative and not as the narrative itself. However that said, from the older shows that I’ve seen that mech centered, I enjoyed much more thoroughly then I do now a days, I feel that the fact that the mechs are drawn 100% of the time adds something to the viewing experience. Enough on that though, everything else looks superb, battle sequences are done superbly and all of the small details make for fun action when it is needed, and nice looking scenes when they are called for.\n
In terms of the music, there isn’t much that I should have to say, it was eye opening to say the least. Anyone who has watched the show knows how good the soundtrack is, I personally have several of the songs downloaded on my phone to listen to them whenever I want. The soundtrack is probably one of the most memorable aspects of the show alongside the story and the ending.\n
Finally if you’ve managed to get to the end of this review hopefully I’ve managed one of two things, instill in you the desire to go and watch this show if you haven’t yet, or at least add it to your plan to watch list.

Aldnoah Zero is a futuristic war anime that does a fairly good job of avoiding many of the pitfalls that mecha anime tend to tumble into on a regular basis. In an alternate history, astronauts discover an advanced power left behind by an ancient civilization on the moon. This power allows them to separate themselves from society on Earth and partially terraform Mars, which they make their home. It's not long before war breaks out between the Earth and Mars. 15 years prior to the start of the series, the moon is literally shattered during combat, and somehow the two sides settle into an uneasypeace.


The war is renewed when a visiting Martian princess is attacked by terrorists during a visit to Earth. The forces of Mars descend onto Earth in force. Here's where the series does a great job of not letting the mecha get too far out of whack. The Martians do have some nifty powers in their mechs, but never do they become unexplainably powerful, or lacking any sort of weakness. The earth forces use much less extravagant mechs that are easier to relate to as potentially recognizable military hardware so the conflict isn't entirely alien in nature.


As for the characters, the way the war is setup does allow for a semi-feasible insertion of the stereotypical Japanese high school student cast, war tensions and universal conscription. I did enjoy the way the male lead ends up turning down better equipment as the series moves on, choosing a beat up trainer mech painted neon orange as his ride throughout. It makes the scenario a little more desperate and human.


That said...I don't really like the cast of characters, particularly on the Earth side. Nothing really changes for them. They are constantly on the run and trying to avoid death at every turn. Most of the character development is experienced through the anti-hero(?) a Earthling boy that ends up living among the Martians. From his view you see the inner workings of the Martian society, and it's where the series gets it's somewhat dark, cynical aura from. That said, the series avoids painting either side as innate good or evil, a trap that has easily doomed many a war anime to first level mediocrity. The Earthling hero suffers from a borderline case of “Too badass to relate to” but constantly being outgunned somewhat compensates for this. I would have liked it a lot more if the series showed us a crack in his shell. I liked his calm, matter-of-fact nature, but after awhile I want to know he's still human. As for everyone else, you can take them or leave them. The princess is dragged around by circumstance. So are the rest. I was going to rate this series significantly lower than I ended up doing mainly because of the ending so far. I'm not going to spoil it, but I think it's worth seeing though to the end.

'It is like Code Geass!' they said. 'It questions racism and what it is to be a species,' they said.
'Eggs,' Inaho replied back, his face unchanged by the barrage of compliments.
The fans of Aldnoah.Zero looked at each other and shrug, 'Hey, it is best sort of humor a show like this can make.'
No, no it isn't.
The story is decent. Not much of it memorable, maybe a few 3D animated fight scenes here and there. Humans are fighting... humans. Not martians (as the show loves to point out), just people who live on Mars. Even when the ...ugh, 'Martians' gain overwhelming power, they would still havehuman blood running through them. It makes no sense why they would dissociate completely from the ...oh come on, 'Terrians'?! Who the fuck came up with that sort of conflict? Sure racism can exist between humans, however the only things that are different about the 'Martians' and the 'Terrians' (is that how you spell it?) is where they live. Not skin color, not ethical differences, just financial and living area differences. No human being would ever, I mean ever, think that those two differences means that they are a completely new race.


Art is stunning. I mean, apart from the blatantly crap 3D animated mechas - which are even animated 3D in static backgrounds -, A1Pictures have talented artists that can draw and animate with fluidity and beauty. Maybe the characters have a case of the duckbill-lip syndrome, but the setting and fight scenes are explosively intricate and enjoyable.


The music is the best thing about this show. Sawano Hiroyuki is one of the best composers present in the industry currently. If you are a producer and want to have an awesome dubstep-piano soundtrack, look no further than to Sawano. Even when your story is predictable and ridiculous - or even when your character are as bland as they concrete they destroy with their mechas (we'll come to that soon enough) - if you have Mr. Sawano as a composer on your team, the soundtrack is guaranteed to not flop like the rest of your anime. Great man!

The voice actors were also good, even though their characters limited their ability.


Oh god, the characters. The characters. I mean, come on Gen - wait, he only wrote the first episode? The good episode? Who wrote the rest of it... a Takayama Katsuhiko? That makes sense now. Anyway, the characters are bland and uninteresting. Inaho is a cardboard box that eats poultry that is more rounded than himself. The only other character I remember by name is Slaine - and he is just another emo blond character with identity issues. There was also that princess-girl, what was her name? Asses- no, that is probably the most ridiculous name for a character I have ever seen. Sweet merciful egg- I mean Christ, dammit!


The only enjoyment you can get out of this show are the fight scenes and the amount of jokes you can make out of the bland characters. I watched this show in sub and in the middle of a scene, I turned off the sound and began mocking stupid voices for each of the characters. That made it so much more interesting and I got a lot more out of it. But aside from that, this show bored the fuck out of me.


Overall, I would not recommend this to anyone who has - or hasn't - seen anime in their lives. It will ruin your perception on the whole industry. Do not watch this show. DON'T EVEN STREAM IT. I couldn't finish this one, especially after finding out the ending of season two. Not worth the wait.

Aldnoah.Zero was an interesting anime, to say the least. It had plenty of unexpected turns that made it so I couldn't predict the end halfway through.
Background:
The story revolves around the concept that a long time ago a bunch of people left Earth to colonize Mars. There, they found a mysterious power called Aldnoah that advanced their technology immensely, but could only be used by the select few that swore fealty to the royal line. After some hubbub a decade or so before the story takes place, Mars and Earth got on some pretty bad terms. The story actually begins with the princess of Mars comingto visit Earth in order to establish better relations between the two races. Unfortunately, not everyone wishes for peace and, one attack on the princess later, Mars declares all-out war on Earth in order to exact its vengeance.


Character: 7

The story focuses around two main characters, each on opposite sides of the war. Inaho, the Earth-side hero, is a calm, level-headed tactician who appears to be an expert at taking down advanced technology no matter how much his companions panic. Slaine, the other main character, doesn't really fight for Mars so much as he fights to protect the princess from those who want her dead, which is rather difficult given that friend and foe aren't clearly defined for him. The characters of the show aren't really mold-breaking, but that didn't stop them from growing on me.


Art and Sound: 7

The show looked good and sounded good. The kataphrakt (mecha) in the show are animated well and watching them fight in closer proximity can be terrific to watch. 


Story: 6

Here's the main falling point I found with the show. The show did its best to break away from the predictable mold of what you would expect to have happen. This certainly made each episode interesting to watch and difficult to predict. Unfortunately, sometimes characters seemed to be making decisions on a whim that existed solely to make sure that the show didn't follow a typical occurrence. 

Ex: Char A meets Char B and they should be enemies, but instead they buddy up and eat dinner instead of hashing it out right then and there.

Also: the story ended in a somewhat unfinished way, which is fine since they intend to do a season 2, but it's quite annoying to see such an interesting show decide to leave itself in a cliffhanger.


Enjoyment: 8

Even with the story occasionally making some convoluting decisions about where to send its characters, it's never really a dull ride. Characters might be somewhat tedious at times, but they grow on you over time and the show's unpredictable nature makes it so no one has perfect plot-armor. This imperfect-plot armor makes it so each encounter at least provides some tension as to whether or not a character will make it out unscathed. The fights between different Kataphrakts are entertaining to watch, and provide well-timed breaks from inaction.


Overall: 7

I think I'd hold off on recommending this anime until the second season is underway. The show is certainly good enough to watch, but its uncertain ending makes it somewhat hard to recommend it in good conscience.

I've noticed that nearly all the reviews for this show are quite negative and I'll admit that when I read their reviews, the critiques made sense. However, I feel that people should also see a review of this show from the perspective of someone who enjoyed it. This is only for S1. I'll be making a separate review for S2.
Story
The story basically follows a 2 faction war set-up with one faction being more powerful than the other. The Martians and the terrans have been in a stalemate for a long time now and the supposed assassination of the martian princess who tries to negotiate forpeace starts the war. Although the set-up is nothing really new (other reviews may have mentioned that it's very similar to a Gundam anime plot), the introduction is very exciting and fast-paced. The show also follows the story from 2 points of view, with Inaho providing the Terran's point of view and Slaine providing the martian's point of view. What I especially liked about the show is how it portrays Inaho's (Terran's side) reliance on strategy and quick thinking in order to match and beat the more powerful Martians. I always felt excited whenever they'd meet a new enemy and I'd ask my self "how will they take it down this time?". On the other hand, Slaine's (Martian's side) point of view added supplementary details to the story as he tries to uncover the secret plot by the martian counts (kinda like their generals) against their own princess. It is also through his point of view that the mechanics of the martian's cataphracts (not sure if I spelled that right), its energy source, aldnoah, and the politics of the martian feudalistic system are explained. I will admit that there were some plot holes and that the plot armor got annoying at times (especially when you watch the ending of S1 and the 1st episode of S2) but overall, I still found the plot compelling enough to keep me looking forward to the next episode.


Art

The art was overall okay. I especially liked the designs of the martian cataphracts. I've noticed that some people commented that the "robots" (I'm referring to the cataphracts) in this show were not memorable at all and for the most part, I'd have to agree. However, it didn't really bother me so much. The martian cataphracts were more distinguishable but since they usually didn't last very long (Inaho tends to beat them in 1-2 episodes) I'd understand why they weren't memorable. The terran cataphracts were pretty much standard (imagine "clone trooper" standard but not as memorable) with Inaho's cataphract (think it's named Sleipnir) being the only one to really stand out because of its orange color. The reason why I didn't have much of a problem with this is because it made sense. The terrans, with their inferior technology, relied on numbers and tactics so it makes sense for their cataphracts to be "standard issue". The martians on the other hand had more advanced technology so it makes sense if they had more leeway into designing their cataphracts. Overall, I'd  say that the art was pretty much standard.


Sound

For me, the sound was one of the best aspects of this show. The battle songs/sound will really get you in the mood and they also match the situation pretty well. The only downside is that it was pretty much the same 2 iconic songs throughout the show (S2 included) with some deviations. If you enjoyed the shingeki no kyojin soundtrack, then you might find this show's soundtrack enjoyable as well. (Favorite song from this show is aLIEz because it sounded pretty epic. I'd get goose bumps when I hear it while I was watching).


Characters

This is the part where I'll  agree with the critics of the show. Aside from Slaine, the characters were pretty bland. Inaho was interesting at first. Rayet and Marito might also catch your attention but they never really got any significant character development. In fact, even Slaine doesn't get any significant character development until towards the end of the series (although he will get it during S2). The princess, despite being a main character, isn't even worth mentioning in my opinion and I swear that about half of Edelrittio's lines was "hime-sama". This is really the weakest aspect of the show in my opinion. There are 2 good things about the characters: the romance wasn't forced (no unnecessary harems as far as I could tell) and no one felt ridiculously overpowered (perhaps Inaho because of his insane tactics but I didn't really feel it while I was watching).


Enjoyment

The show has its flaws and yes it was over-hyped but I still found it very entertaining. As I've said, the plot is developed in such a way that I was genuinely excited and looking forward to what will happen next. The ending was a bit of a shocker and could be frustrating for some but I can definitely say that I enjoyed this show. 


Overall

Objectively I'd say that the show is average, but personally I'd say that it's borderline great-above average. If you're the kind of person who wants a solid plot with great character development, then this show is definitely not for you. However, if you simply want to enjoy a fast paced action show with epic battles (ex. SAO less the harem and filler arcs) then you may want to give this show a try.

*I have tried to minimize SPOILERS, but nonetheless they are present*. 
“Only the dead have seen the end of war”. Fast forward a few thousand years, and Plato’s sentiments still hold true today. Aldnoah Zero is a show that demonstrates the different aspects of war and how it is similar to our Earthly conflicts through its characters and the causes and effects of war. If you focus on purely enjoyment, then you will miss out on critical themes throughout the show.
While the viewer is swept along by Aldnoah Zero’s fast progression, the allusion to time and its passage is important to the show’s purpose.Looking at the episode titles alone details the passage of time and how it affects the characters, especially the children and teenagers; going from “Princess Vers” (E.1) to “The Children’s Echelon” (E.3) shows that war doesn’t wait for anyone, and sooner or later you will be dragged into it. Inaho and his friends go from hanging out and enjoying teenage life to manning Kataphrakts in Earth’s fight to survive the Vers invasion, all within a few days. The “Point of No Return” (E.4) brings an end to one fight, but innocence has already been claimed; Rayet sees her father killed before her eyes as a result of the war, and she is affected by this occurrence throughout the show. Even when there isn’t room to breathe or a moment to relax between fights in Aldnoah Zero, the titles “Then and Now” (E.8), “Before the War” (E.10), and “Childhood’s End (E.12) from the latter half of the show stress the importance of how quickly life can change – especially for those affected by war – over a short period of time. 


Character development was minimal at an individual level, but the effects that war had on the populations was evident.  Princess Seyleum was consistently overly optimistic and friendly throughout the show to both Vers people and Terrans; she did not have much, if any at all, character development. Her intent was to get both sides to “set aside their hatred” and stop the war. Inaho is a static character throughout the show, eliciting no emotion and not allowing it to hinder his decision-making during the war. He started in the show as a precocious teenager who, once he knew his objective, would carry out the mission without fault, and he ended in the same way. 


However, Inaho provided insight regarding war that helped build two thoughts as to why war is fought. Toward the end of the show, Inaho asks Princess Seyleum “what does it take to end a war”, to which she responds “well, if both sides wish for peace and set aside their hatred”. At first glance, Seyleum is either playing true to her overly optimistic character or is naïve, since war doesn’t start merely due to anger and hatred, right? That is what Inaho thinks, stating:


“warfare is nothing but a means of negotiation between states. Wars break out even when there is no hatred. Territory, resources, or interests that you are determined to own. Ideology, religion, pride. Wars are fought over those objectives all the time. Meaning that when those objectives are met, the war will end…anger and hatred, those are nothing more than tools to tilt a war in your favor”.


Inaho believes that the Vers invasion is rooted in a desire for Earth’s resources and that the events toward the princess are simply the casus belli. Assuming that Count Saazbaum, the leader of the Knights, is the one who devised the plan that put the show into motion, he provides us with an insight as to why the war started. While Saazbaum doesn’t undergo character development, the loss of (XYZ) is one of the main causes for his hatred toward the Terrans. This, alongside what has been engrained in his mind (and other Vers people) throughout his life, provides the reasoning behind his wish for war. So, who was right, Seyleum or Inaho? It is hard to exactly say given how much detail the show gives us, but we do know that Saazbaum hates Terrans for what they did to (XYZ) and that he stated it is his duty to expand his peoples’ territory, and when one is given power, it is hard to determine if they will make a rational or moral decision.


Finally, this brings us to Slaine, who sees the most development and is arguably the main character. Throughout the show, Slaine is forced to make decisions that weigh on his ties to both Terrans and Vers people as he investigates events. This balancing act between both parties puts him in a grey area with the viewer and also raises the question: where does one draw his alliances and loyalties? Slaine starts off as friend of the princess and she is where his loyalty lies. Keeping this in mind, we watch as Slaine struggles throughout the show to find his identity amidst the battlefield. Where he cries while killing one character, he is mute and unfaltering when being tortured. Both situations demonstrate the mature and difficult decisions he faces and his unwavering devotion to the princess – his only constant throughout the show. And it is with that one constant in his life, when pulled from underneath him, we see what it means to lose one’s sense of purpose and how, when the constant in your life falters or is taken from you, it impacts the individual.


Aldnoah Zero showed us that war is bleak. It affects everyone, whether directly or indirectly. It claims innocence and forces you to make grave decisions no matter your age. It makes you wish for a previous time where the days don’t seem like hours. After all that has occurred along the way, what all has changed? Has the war ended? Was anything resolved? All we can be certain of is that “only the dead have seen the end of war”.

When I saw the first episode of "Aldnoah.Zero", I thought it was exactly like a 25 minute movie. I should have learned (from Captain Earth) by now to turn back instantly.
This anime has three main characters: Inaho Kaizuka (Hanae, Natsuki), Asseylum "Seylum" Vers Allusia (Amamiya, Sora), and Slaine Troyard (Ono, Kensho). Starting with Inaho, here is a boy that quite resembles a robot, mainly having three emotions -- dull, happy, and frustrated. Throughout the series Inaho must be the least developed. However, in spite of the difficulty, Hanae (Kaneki Ken[Tokyo Ghoul]) gave a voice to the young boy. In this part, his voice is soft, breathy, and captures every part of Inaho's ... personality? Lack of one? In any case, Hanae did very well. Next is Princess Asseylum, a young royal who wishes for only peace between her nations and Earth's. She is a very kind and just girl, perfectly innocent and unaware of the ways of the world. Capturing her completely is Amamiya (Akame & Touka [Akame ga Kill & Tokyo Ghoul]), who just continues to amaze me with her voice. Amamiya's voice is soft, delicate, and perfectly innocent. She plays the princess part to a 'T.' Such a talented woman. Lastly (my favorite) is Slaine. Slaine has to be one of the most developed characters, starting from a weakling boy to a determined young man, most loyal to his princess. Slaine became my favorite character for his resilience, innocence, and determination. Qualities that Ono (Kuroko [Kuroko no Basket]) captures quite well. His voice is thin, and light (qualities I personally love). He molds his voice to fit Slaine's character perfectly, especially at the parts where Slaine has been deeply hurt and is crying or close to tears.


I will flat out say that I am frustrated with "Aldnoah.Zero". It has perfect voices, gods as musicians, wonderful animation, and yet the story is filled with plot holes and mostly undeveloped characters. Inaho is probably the least likable character this season because he literally is a robot. He has no emotions, and not much is known about his besides the facts the he has an older sister, his mind is very analytical, and his smiles are rare (and even then they look almost fake). Getting that off my chest, I will continue to the plot. The anime started out wonderful. The introduction to the world contained beautiful art, many intriguing characters, and best of all, Yuki Kajiura's music as well as Hiroyuki Sawano's. From there it went downhill (and I should have guessed thanks to Captain Earth). The show continued only showing Slaine's and a Lieutenant’s pasts. Without reading the summary, I probably would not have understood that Martians and Terrans used to be one and the same. The show continues, almost as if it's making the plot up as it goes along. And it all comes down to one chilling ending, with a note saying " Aldnoah.Zero - Let Justice be done. Through Heaven's Fall - Next January A.D. 2015 "


But if you like mecha animes, you will not be disappointed with "Aldnoah.Zero". The animation is great, and its concept of mechs is intriguing. There is so much detail put into the machines. This 'Aldnoah' power is especially interesting. It's better than electricity, makes the Martians' mechas better in some way, and yet only certain people can use it. If you are a lover of anime for the character development like me, then you may not like this anime. Or it might just be average to you. I did enjoy this anime, but it left me feeling very frustrated.

What happens when you have Gen Urobuchi, Hiroyuki Sawano, and Kalafina all working in the same project? Pure awesomeness you say? You'd be wrong, but it's not precisely their fault... or yours. If you are thinking of watching this series, think again. This is one of those series that start up great but do not live up to their potential. Be warned, if you are a hardcore fan of mechas you will probably want to pass on this anime. I'm serious; I think I didn't hate it precisely because I'm not a big fan of mechas.
Is this series terrible? Personally, I think it is enjoyable,but really underwhelming considering the people attached to the project. Now I have to mention that Urobuchi only wrote the first 3(!!) episodes, so that explains a lot.\n
STORY\n
I'm not a big fan of mechas so I think I enjoyed the story more than a fan of the genre. Still, from my own experience, this feels like Code Geass and Gundam, (that is, politics, deep characters, complex plots, and betrayals left and right) but doesn't manage to even hold a candle to them. I'm not knowledgeable enough to call it a Gundam ripoff, but it’s a common opinion in the forums. After all, there's not a lot originality here, just your typical sci-fi conflict of people living on earth against those who live in space and, in this case, Mars. There are even some Evangelion vibes here.\n
In order to get the full story you are absolutely required to watch the second season, which is not very good. This is because the first season ends with a huge cliffhanger, and if you get this far you will probably be invested enough to continue watching. Think of it as a 2-cour show with a break in between.\n
If you know Urobuchi's previous works, you will know what to expect in terms of plot twists regarding characters. Without giving away details, you will find a lot of underwhelming subversions to his writing. I found myself constantly thinking "Is this really Urobuchi's work? How can this be?" Well, that was before I knew he only wrote the first 3 episodes. The most likely explanation is that Urobuchi's original idea was changed by the rest of the writing team (I read that he actually left the project), probably hoping there would be more seasons. Now the story it's not bad, I kinda liked it but it certainly doesn't live up to Urobuchi's potential. The science behind the titular Aldnoah, a mysterious source of energy, is never explained or explored in detail!! Other sciency aspects of the show are not explained and only hinted at; the show forgoes spoonfeeding entirely for the sake of better pacing. The problem is that this happens frequently in battles, so expect a lot of asspulls. The first episode starts really slow, a lot of infodump in the first half followed by jaw-dropping action on the second half. The 2nd and 3rd episodes are pretty solid, but after that the plot is not that good. So yeah, this goes to show that the 3-episode rule doesn't always apply.

There is enough action each episode to keep those who dislike background information and character development interested. The shows pacing was great for one cour; we followonly a small part of the world, but after three quarters of the way through connect with the rest to face the challenge. What the story is missing is more background information that would help it. We were only given small spoonfuls of history at a time, and I was craving for more. What the show sacrifices in world building, it makes up for in character development. 7/10


The characters make a show, and the characters in Aldnoah Zero are excellent. Slaine shows the struggle of ideals and beliefs. He wants to help the princess he loves, and proves that many times, but after learning different truths over time, fights for a different cause and helps others. He put his life on the line to help another cause and was shot down (literally). There is controversy around the ending of the show; however, Slaine had developed into someone different throughout the show and his ideals changed. Our MC was one of the only faults of the characters in A/Z, alongside the princess. He was your emotionless genius protagonist (that's not actually seen much, right?) who brought hope to those around him. He was rather one dimensional and flat. The princess had a similar role as other  princesses- the enemy that tries for peace. Se Euphie from Code Geass or Nia from TTGL. She wasn't all that original: beautiful, good relationship with MC, father/grandfather is the tyrant who doesn't really care what happens to her, etc. The characters that are important are Marito, Saazbaum, and Cruhteo. Cruhteo makes a great foil to Saazbaum as he desires war to avenge his princess and what he believes in, whereas Saazy wants (more personal) revenge vs the system he's a part of. Both are greatly written enemies that represent the two different factions on the Versian side (both oppose Earth, one would be the supporters of war, others the princess). Marito is a well developed soldier that has to live with shame for the rest of his life for his past decisions (the right decision, mind you). His character shows the horrors of war, as well as the aftermath. 8/10


The art is not just above average, but the CGI works in this anime. A lot of people may disagree, but I think the CGI mecha's look really nice and improve the action sequences. The characters all look normal and have a considerable amount of depth to them (art wise and how they're written).  8/10


The soundtrack is one of the best I've listened to. The OP and ED are fantastic and I didn't even think about skipping them. Each song that was portrayed throughout the anime had tremendous effect- either to elicit emotion, or enhance action. 9/10. 


Overall, I was not bored throughout the entirety and found each scene meaningful. I usually avoid mech anime; however, this one was quite solid. My only complaint for enjoyment would be that there seemed to be a minimum of one action scene per episode, which wasn't necessary for those who like plot development. Nothing really stopping me from giving this a 10 for enjoyment. 10/10


I'd rate A/Z a 8/10 and of the best anime from summer 2014. I'm really excited for A/Z season 2 as there is a lot left unknown.

You ever hear that joke; "Why did the plane crash?" and the punchline is 
"Because the pilot was a loaf of bread"?
In the same way, one could say that Aldnoah Zero 'crashed' as a mecha anime because its protagonist is like a loaf of bread. Expressionless and lifeless. His face remains straighter than my sexuality. 
Inaho, the MC Alpha that's so badass; calm, collected and cunning - he doesn't need intimidating dialogue or brawn to beat his enemies, just his superior intellect. He is the one of the primary reasons I didn't enjoy this anime. I can't relate to a loaf of bread after-all, sowhy should I care when he gets ----- in his --- in episode -- ? Heck, I might have even enjoyed that scene really. 

MC Alpha, is only Alpha because he can conveniently overcome any problem with calculations and scientific shit, or strategies pulled out of his asshole, really. If you thought Inaho's anus was stretched from that Aldnoah Zero Yaoi hentai (probably Inaho x Slaine) you looked at last night, think again. Nearly every episode, despite the Martian mech proving itself practically invincible to pleb Earth weapons, Inaho always finds a weakness within 2 minutes of fighting and makes a game changing play. Bam. 

G fucking G (not even a well played). 


The other MC Slaine, he's just constantly copping shit so often that you're forced to feel sorry for him. The Martian aristocracy throw abuse at him like bronze players throw League games. He gets put in the friendzone by his love-interest the princess because he's so beta. He gets stabbed in the back by Inaho, even though they just worked together and both want to help the princess? His story is intentionally made tragic and kinda pathetic to evoke sympathy.... but this serves as reverse psychology, and instead makes you feel otherwise and  dislike the guy for being such a fuckin beta compared to MC Alpha. 


The rest of the cast aren't really worth mentioning. Girl 1 that has crush on Inaho. Redundant school mates that are later forgotten. Inaho's sister. A war veteran, struggling with PTSD (sounds deep right?), except can't get over his past and does nothing useful throughout the series. A Martian princess who appears to promote pacifism but is totally fine if MC Alpha kills some Martian baddies. 

Mediocre cast.


Characters (solid 3/10) aside though, the plot (5/10) isn't amazing. The premise seems pretty cool and lured me in, Earth vs Mars, I was expecting lots of space battles or some shit. Nope. Watch as Earth gets wrecked effortlessly by bloodthirsty Martians who seem too overpowered for their own good. The typical AZ episode goes like this;


Oh no! What's that? A highly advanced Martian mecha just killed expendable mechas 11/22/33/44/etc. ? Damn, that weapon they have looked super strong when it killed Expendable Squad X, maybe Earth doesn't stand a chance.... but don't worry! MC Alpha willl just pull a plan out of his butthole, and singe handedly carry Earth to victory. Princess! Lend us your magic powers just so we can kill your people to show them how much we want peace :D. Meanwhile in space - Slaine? You wanna help us Martians? Get fucked, you stupid Terran piece of shit, good for nothing, ungrateful dog, etc.


Despite what I feel was poor about this anime, the art (8/10) and sound (9/10) was really great. Good aesthetics, really good soundtrack. Enjoyable opening and ending. Enjoyment-wise however, wasn't super impressed, and more on the disappointed-side. 


Overall, I'd say Aldnoah Zero is decent for a mecha anime. While the fights were pretty much the same, featuring a Martian mecha using strange, unconventional weaponry (I have no clue why one uses big ass fists to try and fist her way through everything... wouldn't laser guns or maybe even regular guns have been fine??) destroy lots of expendable Earth forces, then have MC Alpha cheese the Martian mecha with some crap he's just made up on the spot or even worse, just cheeses them coz they have no clue how to fight on Earth (he beats them with water couple times, ahahaha). they were still slightly enjoyable to watch.

In short: Only watch this anime if you're looking for great combat as well as for the great soundtracks.
Story-wise, it's nothing amazing. Just basically two factions that face off against each other with two protagonists (who are just late teenagers) who are somehow the centre of everything. There is some development but it's nothing that you would really be watching for.
Music-wise, it is one of the best that I've listened to. It is composed by the amazing Sawano Hiroyuki who was responsible for Attack on Titan, Guilty Crown and Kill la Kill.
Art-wise, it's pretty decent, I really liked the space art more than the earthart. Character designs were okay, not my type of art-style. However, I really did love the interior of the mechs which gave a much more interactive sense between the pilots and the vehicle, unlike other mech animes where the pilots just move hte joysticks about and the robot somehow behaves like a ballerina. The wide variety of other mechs (namely the alien ones) also served to prevent repetition of combat.\n\n
Character-wise, it was like Inaho was just created by word searching the list of traits a typical main protagonist has without even bothering to develop them. He just has... them... right from the start. Slaine was a little better than Inaho in that he had to work his way to his goal. Despite not even seeing each other most of the time, they seemed to share more interaction with each other than with their own faction members.\n\n
Enjoyment-wise, it was great... at least from watching the combat. It wasn't just your cookie cutter, Mr. X throws kick/punch or shoots and Mr. Y defends or hides. Every fight was different due to the different mechanics of the mechs. So sometimes they fought against a guy with a sword, sometimes a guy who could use lightning, sometimes against a guy with invisibility... there was a plethora of different approaches to defeating the seemingly invincible enemy. This is what made the show great.

Aldnoah Zero isn't your normal mechas-fighting-each-other-to-the-death anime. On the contrary, we are presented with an anime that pretty much focuses on 'how' you fight than 'with what' you fight. 
Starting off with the opening theme. The opening theme gives off the feel of the anime itself. It starts off peacefully and just branches into the suspense that you feel througout the anime. Afterwards the theme goes back into an emotional mood to emphasize the 'what is right' aspect of the anime.
While the initial intro for the characters is very confusing at first, they each get traits that define them as individuals (except maybe Calm) throughoutthe anime. Although the protagonist is unrealistically intelligent, that is simply a minor flaw.


As far as story goes, It's main appeal is the cleverness of the protagonist Inaho and the character development of Slaine.  Another theme the anime executes nicely is the nature of war and the righteousness of the participants in a war. The presence of Aldnoah has changed the world greatly in this anime, and it's caused the development of this great storyline.


Overall this is an anime that caters both to mecha lovers and tactical thinkers. Even if you don't particularly like Gundams or the like, I would recommend this anime.

I am not going to say what the show is about in this, just going to keep it basic. The story is very interesting, and I was actually drawn into the plot. The mech's on the Terran side a pretty low-tech, which is the stuff I like. I only have two complaints. One, the main character was a bit distant to me, though I still liked him. He just didn't have a lot of development. Two, the ending drove me crazy. I won't spoil anything, but I will say that 9 out of 10 people are going to be pissed off. Thankfully there will bea second season in 2015.

I will start off by saying, I enjoyed this seriously IMMENSELY despite it's issues. It is VERY Gundam Seed-like (I will be clear, I am not calling it a ripoff - though they are similar at the core, they went there own way with the genre/ideas/basic premises/etc) and as Gundam Seed is one of my favorite anime (and is, thus far, a far better anime) I thought I'd probably enjoy this series. And I really did.
Story: 7.
The story is given a 7 as it isn't terribly original - however, it is a nice spin on the basic ideas of misunderstanding, war, racism, greed and envyplaced in a similar setting to the Gundam Series with the added layer of originality that is the Aldnoah power/drives.  As I enjoy these types of futuristic stories that echo issues of the past, this story was up my alley - however, I felt the 12 episode layout didn't allow it to dig deeper, flush itself out and really go where it could have, so it falls short of it's potential for me. Basically, you have two separate human factions - Earth and Mars -  fighting over differences and resources, a mysterious power that people found on Mars and used to create a Kingdom there, present vs past in the democratic vs monarchy governing systems, a princess who craves peaces and ends up as a tool to ignite war and these two boys, fighting on opposite sides, who share something very special. In it's future seasons, I want it to dig a little deeper, bring more light to the Aldnoah power and Vers - which is where it's unique. Very enjoyable storyline, but it can be better.


Art: 8.


Aldnoah Zero has a very appealing art style with detailed backgrounds, great character designs and tons of detail and colour. Where it falls short is the CGI, clunky mech designs which took me a LONG time to get use to. I had the same issue with Tokyo Ravens (the mech designs looking clunky and out of place) however I did warm up to them a bit but I did feel they took away from the rest of the art displayed in the series.


Character: 6.


I liked the characters but they were nothing new. Inaho is a stoic, calculated un-emotional genius, Slaine is a tragic, unrequited love type ruled by his emotions (rather, a singular emotion), etc.  The secondary characters are appealing, but not developed as well as they should have been. LT. Marito is the only one (of the secondary characters) who's character was really developed and I felt they still could have done more with them. A little more character development and adding some more layers to the main characters - to make them stand-out a little and have some depth, would enhance this aspect of the series. They were enjoyable characters, they just weren't unique or particularly well developed - the seed was planted and if they go the right direction during the second season, I think they can greatly improve on the characters next season.


Sound: 10

I haven't been this blown away by the sound of a series since Guilty Crown. The level of quality in EVERY single piece of music in this series was breathtaking - the openings, the endings, the soundtrack - were all godly in quality and I enjoyed every piece immensely. It added layers and layers to each scene, set the perfect mood before and after each episode and the music really stayed with me after I finished the series. 10/10 for music.


Enjoyment: 8. Though the series needs to dig deeper with it's characters and really focus on developing the characters naturally and further develop both the story and it's background, the series is very enjoyable with it's high action scenes, brilliant ost, beautiful art,  and appealing though not particularly unique characters. It needs to dig deeper with both it's characters and it's story, set itself further apart from the Gundam Series, which has already walked this road and really focus on bringing more attention to Vers and the Aldnoah Power - as that IS what sets this series apart and it's an interesting treat they are dangling and teasing but not digging into and I can't wait until they do.


Overall: 8.

The story is relatively standard fair with Martians invading Earth. It has a few tweaks that set the Martians up with super robots vs the Earths more real robot tech but Aldnoah.Zero is pretty much a bad Gundam clone. A lot of the plot decisions are contrived and someone should have said something about them while they were still in the planning stages of the show.
The characters all look like skinny little bitches but the machines and backgrounds look pretty good.  You can't really complain when it comes to the animation and all the motion looks pretty solid. No complaints.
The music score is amazing.At the end of the first episode it leaves you pretty hyped for the second. It makes this anime sound about 75% more epic than it actually is. I watched the sub before the dub came out and it sounded like a sub. I can't understand the words so I can't really describe the voice actors but they sounded normal.\n\n
The characters pretty much suck universally. They are either useless and single dimensional, stupid as fuck, or a crazy as motherfucker. It's one thing to have characters with human flaws, but its another thing entirely to have characters that are flawed because of bad writing.\n
Kaizuka Inaho - This guy seems pretty cool at first.  He is a badass normal in a training suit. You would think this would make him interesting. The problem is that he is not only auto win against the Martians which destroys any form of tension that could happen--he is just about the only Earthling that is capable of fighting Martians. It is fucking stupid. This should be a pretty one sided war but somehow Earth is still holding on. Character development: N/A. His name should be Gary.\n
Troyard Slain - Slain is almost an interesting character. He is an Earthling that lives on Mars. This shouldn't really matter because Martians all came from Earth anyways but fuck logic, right? This dude has a tone of character development over the course of the show; he goes from whiny to batshit crazy. Normally this is the kind of character I can get behind but his motives and decisions are contrived. He is a poor attempt at a Char clone.\n
Vers Allusia, Asseylum - AKA Dumb Bitch. She is based on the standard princess vying for peace mold that includes Marina Ismail and Lacus Clyne. Like the former and unlike the latter she also spends the entire show being absolutely useless, and even detrimental to her cause. There is no good reason that anyone should be crushing on a cockroach like her.\n\n
As you can probably tell, I did not particularly enjoy this show. I constantly hoped that  would win me back but it fails at every opportunity. The amazing score is wasted on trash like this. I would only recommend this if you are really good at ignoring the flaws in plot decisions.

Let's get this straight, this anime is a rip-off of anime greats we've had in the past; although it delved off into its own domain in the second season -albeit, not so much as it should've- the first season reeks of code Geass
___
FAIR WARNING. THE FOLLOWING IS A SH**LOAD OF SPOILERS. I CAN'T HELP IT. ALTHOUGH IT DOESNT GIVE AWAY THE STORYLINE ITSELF, IT'LL GIVE YOU AN IDEA (AND IT WILL SLIGHTLY TOUCH UPON THE SECOND SEASON)
___
•As you should realise, it is a mecha themed anime, like code Geass.
•Its main theme is human vs. humans in a bid for supremacy; particularly the Martian humans (dueto their supposedly superior Tech). This is reminiscent of the Britannian empire being supposedly superior, watch'em Both as I tell no lie!\n
•They both feature a beloved death\n
•Both protagonists share a justifiable claim to their cause and the following states the character each mimics:\n
Code Geass                     aldnoah\n
Suzaku.                             Slaine\n
Lelouch.                            Inaho\n
But when it came to morals, these roles had become rather fluid.\n
It was weird to see this interchangeable behaviour, but it probably came as a result of attempts to differentiate. So why is it such?\n
So slaine had the technical superiority with the kataphrakts -basically, aldnoahs answer to create geass' knightmares- but lacked the strategic superiority imbued within inaho; both of which display similar odds to that of suzaku and lelouch in code Geass. Furthermore, is treated as a more honourary figure (again mirroring suzakus role) i.e. he is a  “terran” (name given to the earth-born) that was allowed to become a citizen of Vers, this honourary position had left Slaine open to discrimination by those that felt he was undeserving. \n
To top things off, he ends up being in the control of a superior kataphrakt called tharsis of which had specs not dissimilar to code geass’ suzaku's Lancelot knightmare-frame and they -suzaku and slaine- got through a series of rank promotions etc. Etc. \n
When I had said their morals were interchangeable, this becomes visible when we have know what the two protagonists' goals were; and here is where Slaine assumes the qualities of lelouch as in “he had a noble cause that, along the way, had deviated,” but in this case the comparisons remains a little more ambiguous.\n
Now, I’ve said a lot about Slaine's role, but how about Inaho's; in terms of position, he shares the fate as lelouch and had many adversaries and obstacles to overcome (which I will explore when explaining the anime itself... [Cue Yoda voice] ‘so annoying, it was.’). In regards to his goal it steered more towards selfish than noble as he found a girl that he likes and he tried taking out the guy who saved him to stop the girl that he likes from being taken away...\n
SPOILER ALERT\n
That 'guy' was slaine, and he had a better thing going on with the girl in question anyways\n
___\n
Back to my main point, he had the same character style as lelouch also in the fact that he was primarily a strategist and also had the same ‘pseudonym' – I say pseudonym, but in Inaho’s case it was more of a nickname and the was Mustang 00, barely any different to lelouch's Zero.\n
Other than that, there was also the use of “Orange” as a sort of taunt and the fact that Inaho eventually got a special left eye that gave the terrain humans another advantage. \n
Yet they still remained below the Martian humans in terms of technical superiority\n
...\n
Onto the anime itself, I can’t say the storyline was great since it was imitation but I also cannot say it was bad as that wouldn’t do code Geass justice, so for this I left it a 6/fair\n
I guess it was trying to make for some more lighter themed differences to code Geass as that pulled our heartstrings due to the deaths and made a poor attempt to reverse our anguish; so it effectively made an attempt to make the deaths meaningless, but forgot that death itself was the defining factor of our love for the anime.\n
However, the dissent built up is not about its similarities it had to code geass... It’s nice to see someone riding the coat-tails of a great anime for a more similar attitude towards theirs. Because in hindsight they realise that it has backfired and will now become the butt if a joke for copying another anime’s storyline, I bet the creator didn’t even catch on to this as they may have felt that they’ve created a sad story that must be rectified -i mean more often than not, it happens!\n
But what ticked me off is that fact that to the creator, superior technology is not superior... Any ill-constructed plan can take them out. Why is it that the creator did not understand the fact that nobody goes into battle guns ablazing 'cause they gave superior technology, for some reason the Martian humans were passed Off as dumb as they couldn’t comprehend the fact they got outwitted by the enemy coming straight at them. That’s the anime in a nutshell.\n
As for the art, it was body when it came to the characters e.g. their eye shape, but such shortcomings were only natural when dealing with anime/CGI blends; however, the CGI fight scenes were so action-packed whilst remaining ever so fluid, that it became the main reason why I continued watching both seasons and was inevitably let down\n
Most characters were known at face value and the only ones with the deepest construction were the two protagonists; that being said, they were just rip offs of lelouch and suzaku’s so not all that great. They tried build up the supporting characters but it never worked and so they remained in the sides e.g. they attempted to build on a character suffering PTSD. It didn’t work out.\n
One thing’s for certain. I did not enjoy that anime, I was too busy picking out what it had taken from code Geass\n
“turned out to be a lot!”\n
P.S.\n
From what I’ve written, you can see that the anime did not have as much unique substance as it’s substance was derived from code Geass.\n
___\n
Hope you enjoyed what I wrote, and thanks for reading\n

First of all, I was very excited to see this anime but after completing it, I was rather disappointed.
The story is really good, mankind vs martians. Here, the martians are also inhabitants of Earth who left it a long time ago and return to take over it because of it's natural resources like air, water etc.
If you're expecting massive mecha action, fighting robots, superpowers, then that's not what you're gonna get.
The battles are mostly based on strategy where low class robots defeat elite class ones based purely on teamwork, strategies and exploiting weaknesses. There is very less brute action.
The character designs aren't one to droolover. I think the best character was of the protagonist. The others just look like plain old characters, no special design or anything.\n
I'm not saying this anime is bad, some episodes really get me pumped up but they are only a few. This anime was not worth all the hype created.\n
Even though I rated it 8, it's good and you won't feel like it was a waste of time to watch it but still there are tonnes of anime of the same genre that are much better than this.\n
I guess most of it is due to the incomplete ending of this season.\n
Let's see what happens in season 2. I've got a hunch it's going to get much better.
