Quite a lot of the reviews here on this are unfairly harsh on Aldnoah Zero. Most of it seem to be because of overzealous "loyalty" to the "originals", ignorant of the fact that the theme of Homeworld vs. Colonies (usually Earth vs. Mars) is a very common trope in science fiction. From classics like Greg Bear's Moving Mars and Ursula K. LeGuin's The Dispossessed to newer stuff like James S.A. Corey's The Expanse series. Gundam did not invent it. Any review whose only point of comparison is Gundam betrays a very limited perspective of science fiction.
With that rant aside, Aldnoah Zero stands on its ownquite well with the genre. The plot is a familiar one, but still a good one. Touching on topics like war, xenophobia, revenge and forgiveness, social stratification etc. Lots of twists and turns in the political intrigue as well. 


It's somewhat "hard" sci-fi, so while the technologies are more advanced they admirably remain within the realm of scientific believability (with the exception of the alien Aldnoah tech, of course). Things like G-LOC  to even the accuracy of a world map post-sea level rise. 


The overarching theme is that of underdogs fighting an overwhelmingly more powerful force. Big emphasis on overwhelming. They are rats fighting lions. But that fact in itself contributes to why the fight scenes in this series is truly enjoyable. Because science is used in the tactics itself, turning the tide on seemingly hopeless scenarios in a way that leaves you cheering.


Graphics is beautiful, with both hand-drawn and CGI art. Unlike some of the newer anime fans here, I am not a CGI snob. I grew up on pre-CGI anime so I fully appreciate how CGI make some scenes in modern anime far better than they could ever be if they were purely hand-drawn. However, I am of the GITS school when it comes to mechas. I have a dislike for designs which are deliberately form over function. Too many of the mechas (at least the Martian ones) are designed like this, taking design cues from insects, mythological figures, etc. More like toys than actual war machines. 


Character-wise, it's split between very good to very bad. Most of the characters are complex with their own motivations. Even the main antagonists aren't just mindlessly evil. They have their own rational reasons for doing the things they do. However, the way they depict a lot of the minor antagonists isn't as good. They invariably depict them as maniacal, one-dimensional monsters who seemingly have zero empathy. And lastly is one thing I despise immensely - fan service. There are bits of it throughout the series. Not a lot thankfully, but when they do occur, they are blatant and distracting.


Overall, it's a very good space opera. Not exactly breaking new ground, but still very good. Leave all comparisons with Gundam at the door and you'll enjoy it.

Disclaimer: This review contains minor spoilers in the character section, nothing plot-ruining or upsetting, it gets revealed in the first episodes.
I've noticed that this anime has a lot of mediocre reviews (not a comment on the reviews themselves, a comment on the ratings given) and I would like to throw my hat in the ring. Aldnoah.Zero S1 is one of the few animes I have actually rewatched, I enjoyed it, although I couldn't help but draw a lot of parallels to Code Geass, my favourite anime, which may have changed my grading for it.
Story: All-in-all I don't think that it was a bad story, fairlystandard for what I've seen of mechas, not a genre I particularly enjoy. I did notice a few similarities between the story of this anime and that of CG, but I won't discuss them here. I did enjoy both though, keeping that in mind, I believe that this was a good story with a few twists and turns, but it also contained a few plot holes here and there. 7/10, maybe 7.5/10.


Art: I didn't see too much stunning art, and with the animation used for some of the mecha fights, I see why the main character has no facial expressions due to the budget, but I did really like the smoothness of some of the fights, as well as the pretty stunning Earth imagery. 8/10.


Sound: I think that this anime had a fairly decent soundtrack, but nothing to write home about. I did really like the OP and EDs though. 7/10.


Character: Let's isolate Inigo and Slaine in these. Inigo, was not the best character, in my opinion. He had a bit of a, emotionless mastermind feel to him at times, with his extraordinary strategic abilities given his age, but I feel like it could've been done better (as it was in other animes with similar protagonists), I myself cannot offer any real suggestions on how it could have been though. Maybe some more character development as to why he is expressionless and monotone, instead of "just 'cause". Slaine, was amazing, easily my favourite character, he had his motives clearly set out, he had an interesting backstory developed and explaining his situation and I think he was really well done. Some people complain about the simplicity of his motives or his occasional lackluster, but not all young adults have extremely convoluted and in-depth reasons, maybe just helping to save someone that saved you and made your life bareable? All of the other characters, I felt were a bit lackluster, and could have been done better (except Marito). Weighing all of these factors, I'm giving it a 7/10 on characters.


Enjoyment: The fact that I was excited when a season 2 was announced and I rewatched this series (as well as tried to make an abridged) speaks volumes over how much I enjoyed this show. I'm going to give it an 8/10, if I take into account it's absolute worst moments, but it was overall pretty enjoyable for someone who deosn't really like mechas.


Overall: This was a good anime for me. I liked one of the MCs, but I also drew a lot of parallels to others I had seen. I liked the OP and EDs, as well as a few tracks from the OST, but apart from that, not much of the soundtrack. The animation was pretty smooth overall and some of the Earth visuals were aesthetically pleasing, as well as how cool some of the fights were. Overall I'm giving this a 7.5/10, or with rounding an 8/10. I would recommend it, but to those willing to go in without analysing too much.

Aldnoah.Zero more like Aldnoah.Zero/10 haaaaaaa-ah well it's not quite that bad but I'll try to adequately explain why. 
Story:
AZ is for the most part a pretty blank example of what skeleton of mecha story looks like with no meat on it aside from fleshy genitalia dangling back and forth that has [s]NO LOVE DEEP WEB[/s] Urobutcher written on it. 
It has it all. Pointless and undeveloped romance, politics with no reason to care about them, child pilots that are for some reason better than any adult soldier on Earth and unsubstantiated rivalry. Throughout all this there's glimpses of something good but don't leg me deceiveyou, it's straight up bad and whenever there's potential for something more it's quickly vanquished. It's obvious that Urobunchi had stuff planned out throughout first season but then left and they let monkeys with typewriters improvise what happens between those planned plot points. What they came up is pretty funny to watch at times like when they have a little girl drive a huge truck through enemy fire and explosions or when an exciting, plot important alliance is formed but then import part of that alliance is blown sky high minutes later or when main character shoots down the plane of a character who saved his life cause he might be an enemy spy but then gives back a gun to an actual spy who got onto the ship to assassinate the VIP and almost did just that twice. Oh and it's pretty funny when get the balls to kill off two main characters except there's hardly a reason to care about them and I'm pretty sure they'll somehow be alive in S2.\n
The only legit good part of the writing for me were the fights that featured striking down superior opponents by strategizing and figuring out their weak spots. It still has some convenience and the show was too scared to kill or injure named characters which removed quite a bit of tension but it was still fun to watch. \n\n
Art and animation: Mediocre. The backgrounds are unremarkable digital paintings with a lot of shortcuts done through 3D software and cheap texturing, in some points you can even easily see that they added elements of backgrounds solely through textures so when looked at angle it looks completely flat. Character designs are also pretty unremarkable but at least there's no same face and you can easily tell anyone apart. Robots are neat, martians had an array of slick and original designs and even though they look very busy at times it's still good. Earth on the other hand had a walking box that looks lamer than GMs. \n
Animation rarely goes beyond average aside from few fights but generally it's solid and consistent even if not in any way outstanding. \n\n
Music: it's Sawano which at his most "euhkay". It doesn't stand out from his other compositions and even the trademark Kobayashi track is somewhat forgettable but it gets the job done to set mood for important scenes. \n\n
Funfactor: it's kind of a funny trainwreck at times and fights are decent but otherwise a complete waste of time.

This show was absolutely fantastic! The story was deep and pretty interesting, telling the tale of how human have once left to live on Mars and now they want to go back to Earth and take over with their advanced technology. The story starts with a Princess who travels to Earth to make peace and tries to rejoin the two nations as one, but fails when a group of people try to sabotage her being on Earth. She then groups up with our main characters, one of which is incredibly dull and acts like a robot for most of the show. The other characters however all have their own personality, but the main focus of the show wasn't the characters them selves, so over the episodes you will see more action and story telling than you will see character development. Although only a few characters go through a character arch, the few that do make the story change drastically and it was pulled off extremely well. Also I want to add the music just made every scene. They used the same songs throughout the show (like most anime) but the songs they used were beautifully made and well used. The show kept me interested all through, and I enjoyed the story as well. Make you when you watch it to pay attention to what is happening as well as what the characters are going through and what may change.

This series overall has the general concepts of mecha genre with two factions, however if I was able to rate the story higher I would for the sheer reason that each episode beckoned me to watch another which I did not find prevalent in quite a few other mecha series.  Minor Spoiler Alert: Princess Asseylum a royal envoy of Mars goes to Earth in order to usher in a treaty to provide peace between the two planets however little known to her some people have plans on using her arrival to start a war under false pretenses.  This ends up with the princessgoing into hiding and being unable to contact her planet the nobles of Mars plummet in their giant castles to Earth hellbent on vengeance.  SERIES HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Story: We've all seen mecha anime before, but I know a lot of people who enjoy this show, and with good reason. The story is pretty interesting. There are two nations existing in this world, those who live on Earth and those who live on Mars. For years, they have been at war with each other until the Princess of Mars, Asseylum, wants to travel to Earth to make peace between the two planets. However, a terrorist attack has been put in place to make sure the two planets stay in war forever. A group of high school students, led by Inaho Kaizuka, are pulledinto the army in order to finally bring peace to both nations. You'd think this would be a generic story, but actually, it's a lot more complex. Perhaps maybe a tad bit too complex. A lot of side story goes into this, but I do admit that it's a lot easier watching the dub version than the sub. That way, the plot is better told. Almost a full score, but I'd rate it 9/10.


Art: The anime is really pretty to look at, and the action scenes are pretty cool to watch. I feel as if that every shonen show that I watch has a certain style, and this show does have a style all it's own. Sometimes, I feel as if more could be done with it though. I wish it could be larger than life at times, but only the first few episodes give me that feel. Otherwise, it's kinda nothing special, but at the same time it is. It's confusing; I know. With that said, I'm gonna rate this an 8/10.


Sound: I'm in love with the opening to this anime. The soundtrack in general is very good, but this anime made me become a Kalafina fan. It's very catchy, and the ending songs are also great (very famous at that). Out of the two endings, the first one, A/Z is my favorite. I don't know what it is about it, but I love the singer the most. However, Heavenly Blue is considered to be one of my favorite anime openings ever. Again, the music inside the anime is beautiful as well. Everything fits the setting, and nothing seems out of place. With that in mind, I rate this a perfect 10/10.


Character: Each character is pretty much either a very great hit or a very bad miss. I actually split the characters down by race strangely enough. The Martian characters seem to be a lot more interesting than the Earth characters. Look, I'm probably in the same boat as all of you. Inaho is straight up boring. He has every single Mary Sue trope in his body, and I can't feel anything for this kid. His sister is a lot more interesting than he is. However, the only Earth character who sparks my interest the most is... (Sigh) Slaine. He's an adorable person (What I mean by adorable, I mean I want a body pillow of this guy so bad!). I mean, the ending makes me go "What the fuck?" but you feel more for this kid after the shit he's been through. Plus, his friendship with Asseylum is like something from a Disney movie. It's perfect. Speaking of Asseylum, she's no sitting duck when it comes to this anime. She is the only person in the anime who is truly the hero with all the work she does with the people of Earth. She makes the plans. She does everything in her power to keep Martians and Terrians at peace though her kingdom might as well want to destroy her. She's one of my favorite female characters ever. With that said, I would rate this portion an 8 out of 10.


Enjoyment: I guess I'm pretty biased, but I really liked this anime, and I can't wait to get started on the second season. What really stood out for me? Well, music, kinda the anime style, Slaine Troyard, Princess Asseylum, and the fighting scenes. This anime was almost perfect, but it was very good. Personally, I loved every minute of it. That's why I rate this 10/10.


Overall: If I did the math right, this show was a straight up 9/10. I highly recommend you watching this show for all you science fiction lovers out there. I mean when you get past all of the boring characters, down underneath, there is some gold in this show. Excuse me while I go fangirl about the second season when I finally see the dub of it. Oh, and I do recommend the dub as well. It's done pretty great, and again, it's easier to understand the plot that way.

Princess Asseylumwho is the princess of mars comes to earth in attempt to make peace between each other but then war starts between earth and mars, then causes the people of mars wanting to kill everyone on earth. One of the problems I found in the story is how it uses terrible plot twists that don't make any sense and are just done to further the story. Another problem I found is how the story always makes the humans win each battle even though throughout the anime it shows that the martians are much more technologically superior than the humans are which ruins the potential of making the characters look like that they are all fighting for survival. My final problem with the story is how the ending does a lot of things that don't make any sense and it just leaves it ending very unsatisfactory.


Art and Animation: (7/10)


The art in this anime is very good. The voice actors are all fine and the sound effects are all average.


Characters: (2/10)


I think that the characters are the main problem in Aldnoah.Zero. All the characters are easily forgettable with them getting hardly getting development and some even getting no development. The characters that I said that get no development are the other pilots of the mechs because all they are there for is just to be killed and when they are killed none of the characters don't even care that they died. Kaizuka Inaho, our main character, is a terrible character. Enjoyment: (5/10)


The only things that I enjoyed in this anime were the giant mech fights, the visuals and the soundtrack.


Overall: (5/10)


I think that Aldnoah.Zero has many good looking action scenes from time to time but even if it has that it is still an anime that is not worth watching due to all the problems that it displays throughout all the anime.

Code Geass, but written by the guy who wrote Fate/Zero.
Character: 4
Aldnoah.Zero is a story that values the plot over it's character. All the characters have a solid personality, and are distinct, but none of them really go through much development throughout the series. This is with the exception of Slaine Troyard, who goes through drastic and realistic character changes, and breaks the slap on definition of "Good guy" and "Bad guy". Story: 7
The seriesdelivers a fun plot with a fair amount of twists and turns that can make your jaw drop. There is a bit of a lull in the middle, where everyone goes around just doing repetitive fights, but the fights are intelligently executed and fun to watch. Art: 8\n

Bit of a rant coming here, I'm rather P-O'ed. "Aldnoah.Zero" is a big ol' swing and a miss at an attempt to make a great Animé genre. It hits all the boxes on the "Do It Yourself" Animé starter pack checklist:
Does it take place in a school?
Only early on, but they keep their uniforms the whole time. So, close enough. Check.
Is the lead character a pretty, tomboyish, but still feminine girl or a super serious, spiky-haired boy?
Minus the spikey hair, but so serious I thought it was gonna be revealed he was a Terminator. Check.
Is there a supernatural or fantasy element that centers the plot?
"Aldnoah"is pretty much slang for "Magic plot device". Check.


Are there fight scenes with guns, handheld weapons, or magical powers?

Giant robots powered by magic! Check.


Is there a mid-series break to make one season like two?

Yes, but it's a doozy. Check.


Is there an obligatory fan service episode at a pool/hot spring/beach so all the female characters can be seen in swimwear? 

Major plot point happens in the shower. Check.


Hard to believe this is from Gen Urobuchi, who gave us "Fate/Zero" and "Psycho Pass" and many more. But, seeing it takes place in a dystopian future makes it rather obvious. Also rather obvious is the lack of originality in this series. So much been there, done that! Martians invade Earth. Giant robots. Man on a quest to save a Princess. Conspiracies. It's a potpourri plot. That sucks.


The art is pretty standard, but it has it's moments. Supplemented by a lot of CG and some pretty decent SFX. The music is your standard "let's add choirs to this  to make it sound really epic" score. The sound effects are decent.  But, the characters- OMG WHAT A TRAIN WRECK!  Let's look at some of those featured at the Grand Central Station of disappointment:


A main character so bland and boring, you could have replaced him with a block of tofu and gotten more emotion. 


The faithful servant who must save his Princess. (Holy Link, Batman!)


The Princess who is beautiful, naive, pure hearted, magical, and only wants to do good and make peace but now everyone wants to kill her. (complete with her obligatory maid who's job it is to follow and guard her like a puppy while constantly repeating, "Your highness..."). 


The ex-soldier with PTSD who drinks too much. 


The comic relief best friend who acts like a goof in front of ladies.


And bad guys who's job it is to be bad snobby and evil. They are so one-note, they make Disney villains seem subtle and complex! The most interesting character in this show is Rayet. But just because everyone else sucks. Sub vs. Dub goes to Sub by default. The Japanese cast is decent, the English cast is lousy. Dishonorable mention goes to Eddelrittuo, who is voiced by the human squeak toy that is Sandy Fox (stick to Betty Boop!)


The strongpoint of the show is it's really cool mechs called "Kataphrekts". The bad guy suits are big, powerful, intimidating, and wipe out most of Earth's generic looking cannon fodder suits providing a bit of sweet, sweet, 'splosion porn that mech fans live for. The excitement stems from seeing how they're gonna defeat each seemingly invincible foe that shows up. And it's usually done using sound tactics that are believable. Shame the writers couldn't have used those smarts to come up with something more original than a flying battleship! Grr...


The reason I didn't completely bury this season was because of a strong and balsy ending. The kind of shocking moment you expect from a work of Gen Urobuchi's. It took some guts and outside the box thinking to do something like that. The show needed more of that and less re-hashed crap. Actually, the show needed more than that, but it saves it from a failing grade. I write this review with clean eyes, having not seen Season 2, so this is only an indictment on the first season and not the show in general. 5/10 (I'm being generous) Check it out if you like mechs or want to fill out your MAL profile. Cheers hoping Season 2 is better!

WARNING: This review will contain early spoilers, and is probably more of a rant than an actual review (also it's my first review so please don't butcher me).
A main character is the core of a story, as most screen time occurs around them and their perspective. 
Aldnoah shifts between multiple perspectives, so I am willing to give it some leeway, however it is undeniable that Inaho (the protagonist of this story) is easily one of the most poorly written MCs. 
If you can overlook the poor story and character design, then you might enjoy this anime, just don't expect too much.
To simply describe the protagonist,he is a self-insert 'Mary-Sue' genius who can achieve anything. I'm not against intelligent characters, I'm against intelligent characters written by stupid people- the protagonist might as well be some kind of magician who knows his enemies' exact next moves.

Have you had enough? But wait, there's more! 

He gets a bionic eye which further leads him down the path of Mary-Sue. Of course with this excellent writing there would be tremendous side effects- wait, there aren't? Just the occasional "ow my eye hurts" for a few episodes.


Not to mention his bland and apathetic personality that makes him less of a character and more of a plot device- speaking of plot devices, one of his friends dies right in front of his eyes, and what reaction does that leave? The heroic "I will avenge you" before he pilots a training mecha to take down an advanced alien weapon. Let me emphasize this. A HIGH SCHOOL student takes out an enemy which groups TRAINED soldiers and veterans couldn't harm at all. 



The story then continues to him killing aliens with advanced weapons, while using inferior technology, over a failed assassination attempt and misunderstanding. Of course everyone is too stubborn (or stupid) to actually try to peacefully put an end to the war, or even reveal that the princess is alive.


Most characters don't attribute anything to the story, and only a handful of main characters are actually important.


To end on a positive note, the animation and art are very good- especially with the heavy action scenes- and the music is also good. I found myself listening to the music even when writing this review (rant).

When Earthlings finally stepped foot onto Mars, they discovered an ancient power known as Aldnoah. This power somehow transferred itself into the blood/DNA of the explorers and now an entire empire exists on Mars, built around the powerful technology. Unfortunately, tensions are at an all time high between the Martians and Earthlings, with Martians operating assault fortresses orbiting the Earth, ready to pound the planet at the first sign of provocation. That spark ends up being a peaceful visit by the Martian princess, who is seemingly blown to bits in an unprovoked terrorist attack. War is at hand.
For ages, we've watched mech shows where theprotagonist is given great powers and must defeat unprecedented numbers of opponents to achieve victory. In A/Z, that premise is turned upside down; the Earth-dwellers must use archaic, outmatched machines to defeat seemingly invincible enemy mechs known as cataphracts. Huge losses are taken by the Earthlings just to stall one of these. Enter our protagonist Inaho, an intelligent reincarnation of the lead from Persona 4. He uses inference and his surroundings in order to even the odds against the Aldnoah-powered Martial cataphracts. The story follows both forces as the war proceeds.


A/Z is a mech-based action thriller with numerous twists and a cliff hanger attached to the end of every episode. It is an engaging watch as for once you're rooting for the underdogs, and constantly figuring out how they'll make it through the next battle. This continues to be the theme all the way up to the end of the first season, which ends on the mother of all cliffhangers. However, from that point, the series starts to grow old as patterns are repeated and space battles end up being your typical beam spam war.


A/Z could have been the start of an awesome franchise but ended up feeling like little more than Valvrave. By all means, it's a very exciting watch, but the actual character development, especially with antagonists, was pitiful at best. If you're looking for a great action show, this is definitely a good choice. If you're looking for something to rival the best of the Gundam franchise, you're going to be disappointed.


Animation:

There isn't anything to complain about in this section, well maybe perhaps the mech designs. I guess I should be happy that they don't look like beetles, but the mechs aren't exactly what I call pretty; they almost remind me a bit of the Arbalest from FMP. I was initially so turned off by the orange mech that I almost skipped the entire show. Mechs aside, the show has very good production values. Expect a modern look with great shading and effects. The show is drawn in a slightly under-saturated palette that gives it an appropriately desperate feel. There is great attention to detail be it in the backgrounds or how mechs are damaged and destroyed. There is extensive usage of CGI in many of the mech fights, but it's pretty good quality and not all that distracting. The only weird thing for me was that the backrests in the Martian cataphracts looks like the inside of a coffin, perhaps on purpose? There are many characters, but all the important characters are reasonably distinguishable. Expressions are very good overall except for our virtually emotionless protagonist and his rival, Slaine.


Expect a hearty dosage of action in this show, the majority of which is mech based; there are a few gun battles on foot as well however. The choreography is very good, especially early in the show where every battle is pretty desperate. Expect the protagonists to always barely escape death. Speaking of death, there is a lot of blood and dying, usually of unimportant or unnamed fighters. You should also expect a protracted battle at the climax. This show isn't ecchi based; don't even expect a Flay-like character as character development seems secondary.


Sound:

The sound production values are likewise high. I didn't really take a liking to either of the two OPs, but all of the EDs (with the exception of the last episode) were exceptionally good. The BGM is also very good, with a wide range of melodies ranging from the calming to the chaotic. It is used to great effect particularly in the battles. There is definitely a central melody along with a uniquely electronic feel. In addition to the music, expect great sound effects as well, examples include shells bouncing off the ground and grossly realistic throw up.


Story:

The story takes a very Gundam-like approach, where seemingly insignificant individuals end up having profound effects on the entire war effort. It also continues the Earth vs. colonies theme and attempts a rivalry between Inaho and Slaine, which seems to attempt to mirror something like Kira and Athrun from Gundam Seed; unfortunately, in this case that attempt falls very short.


You'll see the world presented from two viewpoints, that of our protagonist Inaho and company as well as that of Slaine. Expect a lot of ironies and some political banter, especially from the Martian crew. The story is very clearly divided into two seasons, each of which builds to an astronomical climax. Be prepared to start the second season immediately upon finishing the first season, as the cliffhanger is a big one. However, the tempo in the second season feels very different as it first undoes quite a bit of the first season. It doesn't feel as interesting in that the antagonist's rise to power is both rushed and unnatural. Inaho's originally unique take to battle by now has grown old and so it just feels like more of the same.


The second season also concludes in a very weird way; it feels like they wasted a lot of potential with the route that they followed. To say that I was disappointed is a huge understatement; really, what was all the fighting and bloodshed even for? There are a lot of particulars that I think went horrifically wrong in the second season, but almost all of them involve spoilers in some way or another. If I had to liken what they did in comparison with another show, I'd say the second season of A/Z is similar to the third season of Shakugan no Shana.


Character:

There are some likeable characters in this show; it's just that they all happen to be supportive characters or characters that spend the majority of the show in a tank. Though the show had good attention to individual traits, it really didn't portray either Inaho or Slaine in a positive light. Inaho is an emotionless and calculating killing machine who fights to end the war as soon as possible. Slaine is a mysterious and capable fighter who suddenly becomes an incredible force one presented a mech; Slaine also harbors psychological issues and is infatuated with his own perception of princess Asseylum. Compared to the dynamic nature of characters in other shows, this one falls very short.


The show spends a significant portion of the first season developing character relationships, many of these interesting relationships (not necessarily romantic) in the first season are basically ignored in the second season. As for ease of relating, the primary cast fairs pretty poorly. Even worse are the antagonists who are barely developed as they often just end up being Inaho-fodder. Besides, isn't it weird to send your generals, alone, in front of the rest of one's forces?


Value:

A/Z is like one long roller coaster. At first, it is thrilling and exciting. However, by the end you're just swaying with the turns and really just want the ride to end. To be honest, I was totally prepared to give the show a raving review after the first season. However, the second season wasn't what I had hoped for; it was unable to run with the exciting tempo of the first season and it decided to take a lot of weird turns. That being said, it is still probably one of the more exciting mech shows out there. If you can put up with a story that turns sour in the center and sub-interesting characters, this is an entertaining show. However, if you're looking for the best of the mech experiences, I'd still stick with the Gundam franchise.

Despite being a frequent reviewer on other sites such as YouTube, the anime I set out to watch and review generally please me in some manner or another, with varying degrees of enjoyment. And when I started this show, I had good expectations. But, it dropped off like a cliff and smashed into the ground, splattering whatever creativity it had all over.
First of all, one of the only decent elements of the show is the story, because it is interesting and engaging. The idea of these two colonies of Mars and Earth going to war is a pretty good idea, and while the execution ofit does leave quite a bit to be desired considering the strong idea, I can't say it ruined the anime.


No, that job was done by the characters. Most of them were pretty boring while leaving little impression, but the biggest punch in the nuts was from Inaho. The job of the main character is to be the captain of the ride, the one who leads the coaster through the story. They're supposed to be the one we identify with. Well, it's incredibly hard, if not impossible, to identify with or even care about a character who shows no emotion whatsoever. He shows no caring whenever he's in a fight, and even when one of his friends DIES (not really a spoiler, it happens very early on), he doesn't seem to even care. I've heard excuses, like how he is a high functioning autistic. Which is fine, but there is NO reason for it. I can see an autistic character being interesting, but here it just severely hurts any chance this character has of being likable. He is incredibly bland with few if no identifying traits to make him stand out. So this leaves the audience to the side characters, and the only one really worth watching was princess Asseylum, and even she was only just okay. And the villains, the characters that could've almost saved it, were completely forgettable and left so much to be desired, with weak motivations and few interesting traits. So, the anime fails on the character portion, which might I add, is a key part of any medium.


The animation was fine enough for the most part, and the character designs were okay, but the kicker was the CGI animation. It wasn't very good, and the mech designs were pretty uninspired and bland. The action scenes weren't all that engaging. It's also particularly hard for action to be intriguing if there is no real weight to it. Inaho is almost always on top of things, and this would be GREAT if it was an over the top action that has a lot of comedy and satirical elements, maybe like One Punch Man. But this is supposed to be serious. The characters are almost never in danger, so it isn't serious. It's a waste of time with flashy colors and mediocre CGI robots fighting each other.


The best element of the show is the music, which was actually really good. There was even one track in particular that almost fooled me into almost enjoying the show, until I re-watched it and realized that I was mostly enjoying the songs instead of what was happening.


Needless to say, the anime was not fun. Not completely awful, because there were a few elements that worked, but it was bogged down by such a poor cast and action that wasn't engaging. There was potential here, but it was not reached, not even to a level that made it a fun product. Instead, Aldnoah.Zero is one of the weakest anime I've ever seen, and should definitely just be skipped.

This isn't going to be a very long review since I don't plan on going super in depth, just know that there will be spoilers.
I hadn't had high hopes for this anime from the beginning, it was one that I'd looked at and thought "I'll watch that while I'm waiting for episodes of other continuing anime ." but even so I didn't expect it to be /this/ poor.
It starts off fine and then nose dives into the ground; the plot doesn't make sense, the soundtrack was alright but used poorly (e.g. the same song used for every battle), and the characters make irrational and nonsensicalactions compared to their knowledge and beliefs, you can just tell that these decisions were made by the writer and not the character to shoehorn in some "emotional" or "gosh what'll happen now" moments.


I think what annoyed me most was the story though. You start off thinking it's some cout d'etat by the Vers people framing the death of their Princess on Earth, which is fine, it's a good starting point for a story. My first problem with this is that you discover that only /two people/ of the entire fleet are genuinely nice and want the Princess to live...just two? Really?

Moving on from that you much later find out that the ringleader behind all this has a personal vendetta against Earth, namely his wife-to-be was killed by humans-- but oh wait, later he explains himself further;

It turns out that the Vers people were panicking 'cus Mars ain't a great place to live (which in of itself is bullshit, though I won't get into the science aspect of things) and the Vers royalty were ignoring their people's suffering, to save their own skins the Vers royalty lies to their people and turns them against Earth, they send a landing party to check how good Earth's military is which includes ringleader and wife-to-be. You'd think here is where wife-to-be gets killed by humans right? WRONG. Humans turn out to be no match for the Vers technology and they are winning, when all of a sudden the gate on the moon they'd used to get from Mars to Earth blows up and shatters the moon in the process. Bits of the moon smash into the Earth, wife-to-be is unfortunately killed by moon chunks, the end.


So...why the fuck does the ringleader hate Earth again? Does he blame Earth for the moon spontaneously exploding? How does "chunk of moon killed wife-to-be" translate to "humans killed wife-to-be"? If it was the royalty that messed things up in the first place and the ringleader knows this, why is he going to war with Earth at all? Surely this cause should start a civil war right?


...You see my problem with the story here? There is no motive. The more the reasons behind the attack were explained the less sense it made.

NO SPOLIERS
The overall rate for this anime is 7 because although it is a very exciting action anime to watch it's just that. As far as the story, and the development of it goes, it is a crapy one.Practically there's no trascendental message, and the main characters never trully face a problem that makes you sweat. The thing that makes this anime exciting is all the action that has in it, i LOVED the art and OMFG the soundtrack !! 
I recomend this anime if you're a mecha fan, or if you want to watch an action anime that doesn't require you to use yourbrain. \n\n
